The ruling is a legal victory for special counsel Robert Mueller, who was appointed to investigate Russian interference in the 2016 election. | Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images mueller investigation U.S. judge rejects move to dismiss Mueller indictment against Russian firm

Special counsel Robert Mueller on Thursday scored a legal victory after a federal judge denied a Russian firm’s motion to dismiss charges against it.

Judge Dabney Friedrich, who President Donald Trump appointed to the U.S. District Court of D.C. last year, shot down the motion from Concord Management and Consulting, a St. Petersburg-based firm that prosecutors say financed and organized an army of internet trolls and social media ad buys as well as other tactics to try and sow discord in the U.S. and aid Trump’s candidacy for president.

Story Continued Below

Mueller, who was appointed to investigate Russian interference in the 2016 election, charged Concord as well as two other Russian businesses and 13 Russian individuals in February of this year.

The firm, which prosecutors allege is run by Yevgeniy Prigozhin, a Russian oligarch with close ties to Russian president Vladimir Putin, entered a not guilty plea in court and sought to prove that the charges brought against them were intended only to score political points for the probe and prove its legitimacy.

“The reason is obvious, and is political: to justify his own existence the Special Counsel has to indict a Russian — any Russian," attorneys for the firm argued in May about the reason for the indictment.

Playbook PM Sign up for our must-read newsletter on what's driving the afternoon in Washington. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Lawyers for Concord also argued that Mueller’s appointment was illegal and unconstitutional, a claim that had been rejected by three other federal judges before Friedrich also rejected it in August, while also allowing that Supreme Court precedent and not explicit statutory authority factored into her decision.

That Concord retained American attorneys for the case, and is participating in it at all is viewed as an attempt to get a glimpse of the evidence Mueller’s team has compiled, given that no human defendant will likely ever appear in a U.S. court for the case. Some lawyers believe that prosecutors will end up having Concord struck from the case rather than reveal sensitive information about the investigation.

In Thursday’s filing, Friedrich gave both parties a Nov. 28 deadline to confer on a schedule to move forward with proceedings.

content: Rep. Marcia Fudge has not said whether she will challenge Nancy Pelosi, only telling reporters that she is "considering" the bid. | M. Scott Mahaskey/POLITICO House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi sought to tamp down suggestions that her speakership bid was in t… [+1747 chars]
fulltext:
Rep. Marcia Fudge has not said whether she will challenge Nancy Pelosi, only telling reporters that she is "considering" a bid. | M. Scott Mahaskey/POLITICO Congress Pelosi on potential Fudge challenge: ‘Come on in’ The Democratic leader vowed that she would have the votes to be speaker.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi sought to tamp down suggestions that her speakership bid was in trouble Thursday, brushing off the threat of a potential challenge by Rep. Marcia Fudge (D-Ohio).

In fact, the California Democrat seemed to invite the former Congressional Black Caucus chair to jump into the race.

Story Continued Below

“Come on in, the water’s warm,” she said.

Pelosi’s comments come just hours after her critics said they had 17 names on a document vowing to vote against her on the House floor. POLITICO has verified the signatures of 11 of those lawmakers or candidates-elect, but the group has not released the letter publicly.

Pelosi downplayed the significance of the letter in part because her critics have refused to release the letter at this time.

“Have you seen the letter?” she asked reporters.

Pelosi maintained confidence that she would win a speakership bid if the election were held today.

Sign up here for POLITICO Huddle A daily play-by-play of congressional news in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

She needs 218 votes on the floor, and her allies predict that she will pick off some of the 17 lawmakers and candidates on the document and turn them into supporters by the Jan. 3 floor vote. It’s not clear yet how many Democrats Pelosi can afford to lose, because the party’s majority continues to grow as final midterm votes are counted.

Pelosi also told reporters she would “never” accept help from Republicans to clinch the gavel.

"I have overwhelming support in our caucus to be speaker of the House. … I happen to think, at this point, I'm the best person for this.”

Fudge has not said whether she will challenge Pelosi, only telling reporters that she is “considering” a bid.

author: mcaputo@politico.com (Marc Caputo)
title: Gillum keeps hope alive for election challenge as Florida recount points toward DeSantis
description: Gillum could still contest the election by filing a lawsuit within 10 days of the election being officially certified.
content: So far, Gillum has refrained from caustic remarks or appearing like a sore loser and hasnt been litigious. | Steve Cannon/AP Photo MIAMI At 3 p.m. Thursday, the deadline for recounting the 8.2 million votes in the race for Florida governor, Andrew Gillum face… [+4631 chars]
fulltext:
So far, Gillum has refrained from caustic remarks or appearing like a sore loser and hasn’t been litigious. | Steve Cannon/AP Photo Gillum keeps hope alive for election challenge as Florida recount points toward DeSantis

MIAMI — At 3 p.m. Thursday, the deadline for recounting the 8.2 million votes in the race for Florida governor, Andrew Gillum faces a choice: issue his second concession or refuse to quit, play for time and pray for a mathematical miracle.

The Democrat is likely to pick choice two and yet still watch Republican Ron DeSantis become the de facto governor-elect of Florida, according to people familiar with his thinking.

Story Continued Below

All of Gillum’s hopes ride on a series of unlikely events tied to his fellow Democrat, Sen. Bill Nelson, who has filed a host of lawsuits to broaden the pool of countable ballots by overturning or changing Florida election laws and rules. It’s an unlikely path to victory even for Nelson, who has a smaller deficit in his race compared to Gillum‘s.

But it’s still a path. And if enough votes surface, Gillum could still contest the election by filing a lawsuit within 10 days of the election being officially certified, which is supposed to happen Nov. 30. So Gillum has two weeks to make a decision.

“He’s struggling with the fact that obviously he would like to be governor. But he’s got other things on his mind,” said Gillum’s attorney, Barry Richard, a veteran election law lawyer central to George W. Bush’s recount fight in the 2000 disputed presidential election in Florida.

“Would he have a stronger voice or lesser voice if he filed a lawsuit? If he files a lawsuit, would it diminish his ability to change things?” Richard asked.

Though he's Gillum's legal adviser, Richard's question reveals the broader political concerns Gillum is weighing. The race for governor catapulted the Tallahassee mayor to national stardom and made him a progressive heartthrob. Gillum now has a new fan base — and an expanded donor network — outside of Florida. Some of his backers are privately urging him to consider challenging President Donald Trump.

Some Democrats who backed Gillum privately expressed concern that the candidate would be damaging his brand by drawing out the process of an election contest when he clearly lost.

“It’s train wreck,” said one top backer, who did not want to be quoted for fear of being ostracized by Florida Democrats. “The only people who benefit from this are people who want power, money and the adoration of elements in our party who want to push this because they’re looking at the 2020 elections instead of the good of our state.”

So far, Gillum has refrained from caustic remarks or appearing like a sore loser and hasn’t been litigious. Instead, he has taken the safe position of merely calling for all the votes to be counted, which he’s expected to do again Thursday.

Gillum adviser, Kevin Cate, said his team isn’t concerned about the criticism.

“Andrew’s brand is strong and growing stronger,” Cate said. “This election is not about a moment. It’s a movement.”

Cate said no decision on an election challenge has been made yet, a sentiment echoed by Richard.

Richard acknowledges that an election contest lawsuit isn’t easy. Citing Florida statute, Richard said the likeliest grounds for such a contest, as of now, would be to challenge the results based on the “rejection of a number of legal votes sufficient to change or place in doubt the result of the election.”

But, he said without elaborating, “there’s a lot of different theories, but which ones we would advance in the lawsuit depends on what the evidence is. And you have to have enough votes left over to win the election.”

What does that mean? “We don’t know at this point. We don’t have all the data,” he said.

The Gillum campaign got a small dose of hope Thursday morning when a federal judge ruled that absentee and provisional ballots that were thrown out because of mismatched signatures could be counted if each voter in question cures his or her ballot by 5 p.m. Thursday.

Still, the pool of votes — which could range from 4,000 to 7,800 — is relatively small compared to Gillum’s deficit of 33,684 heading into the manual recount, which Florida law mandates if election results are within .25 percent after a machine recount. Judging by the current election results, those votes would split about equally between Gillum and DeSantis.

Nelson has a smaller deficit in his race against Gov. Rick Scott — 12,562 votes — heading into the likely manual recount to be called today when the machine recount of all the ballots is done. The margin in the Senate race is so small that a manual recount in is scheduled to begin to today.

Richard said Gillum didn’t intervene in Nelson’s lawsuits because “he doesn’t want to litigate for the sake of litigating. There’s nothing to be gained from litigating just to litigate if there’s no reasonable chance that it’s going to make a difference. And there’s nothing to be gained from intervening. It wouldn’t have gotten us anywhere.”

author: Jesus Rodriguez
title: Trump administration slaps sanctions on Saudis over Khashoggi's death
description: The Treasury Department designated the officials for sanctions over what it called "serious human rights abuse."
content: Karen Attiah, Jamal Khashoggi's editor at the Washington Post, tweeted Thursday that "sanctions will not fix this. Its not enough." | Marc Piasecki/Getty Images The Trump administration on Thursday imposed sanctions targeting 17 Saudi Arabian officials but no… [+3838 chars]
fulltext:
Karen Attiah, Jamal Khashoggi's editor at the Washington Post, tweeted Thursday that "sanctions will not fix this. It’s not enough." | Marc Piasecki/Getty Images Foreign Policy Trump administration sanctions Saudi officials, but not crown prince, over Khashoggi

The Trump administration on Thursday imposed sanctions targeting 17 Saudi Arabian officials — but not the powerful crown prince — over the death of Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi more than a month after the Saudi critic went missing.

The Treasury Department designated the officials for sanctions over what it called "serious human rights abuse," freezing any U.S. assets and barring American citizens from engaging in business with them. The announcement named royal court adviser Saud al-Qahtani and said he led the team that flew into Istanbul just hours before Khashoggi entered the consulate there for paperwork relating to his planned marriage. Al-Qahtani was fired from his post in late October.

Story Continued Below

Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, who decided not to attend the glitzy "Davos in the Desert" business and investment conference in Riyadh amid outrage over Khashoggi's death, said al-Qahtani and the other 16 officials were directly involved in the "abhorrent killing" and must face consequences for it. He also called on the Saudi government to "end any targeting of political dissidents or journalists."

"The United States continues to diligently work to ascertain all of the facts and will hold accountable each of those we find responsible in order to achieve justice for Khashoggi’s fiancée, children, and the family he leaves behind," Mnuchin said.

Human rights groups, however, expressed outrage that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who is close to presidential adviser and son-in-law Jared Kushner, was left out of the sanctions.

Members of Congress and many in Washington have argued the crown prince must have known about the operation to kill Khashoggi, but the Trump administration has withheld from making such allegations. President Donald Trump also worried human rights activists when he expressed a hesitation to jeopardize weapons sales with the Saudis over the Khashoggi incident.

While the sanctions ameliorated some of this criticism, lawmakers across the aisle said they should be just a first step in punishing Saudi Arabia and reassessing the U.S. relationship with the country.

Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.), the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who has cast doubt on the notion that the crown prince's hands are clean, said he requested a meeting with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, Defense Secretary James Mattis and CIA Director Gina Haspel to discuss the U.S. response.

"I have a lot of concerns about the trajectory that Saudi Arabia is on right now, and I think a price needs to be paid," Corker said in a statement.

"The administration appears to be following the Saudi playbook of blaming mid-level officials and exonerating its leadership," said Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine, who represents Virginia, where Khashoggi lived. "I will continue to push for further action in Congress to hold Saudi Arabia accountable."

Maryland Sen. Ben Cardin, the top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said he remained concerned that Trump was "enabling the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia" in shielding the crown prince from punishment.

Human rights activists also decried the limited actions.

"The Trump administration deserves some limited credit," said Rob Berschinski, senior vice president for policy at the Human Rights First advocacy group. But: "There should be no doubt that there are sighs of relief in Riyadh at the moment."

Khashoggi's former employer has also long demanded an independent investigation into the situation.

"It is impossible to have confidence that we have gotten to the truth when the purported investigations were neither transparent nor independent and when evidence continues to be withheld," said Fred Ryan, Washington Post publisher and CEO in a statement. "Many important questions about Jamal’s tragic murder have gone unanswered."

And Karen Attiah, Khashoggi's editor at the Washington Post, tweeted Thursday that "sanctions will not fix this. It’s not enough."

In their own efforts to punish people over Khashoggi's death, the Saudis announced Thursday that they were seeking the death penalty for five individuals suspected to have ordered and carried out Khashoggi's murder.

The Trump administration had been previously quick to slap sanctions on international actors, including in Nicaragua, Myanmar and the Gambia, using the Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act, which gives the president broad sanction powers to punish human rights violators. In a statement Thursday, Pompeo signaled the administration might not be done responding to the death of Khashoggi, who was living in Virginia at the time of his death.

"Our action today is an important step in responding to Khashoggi’s killing," Pompeo said. "The State Department will continue to seek all relevant facts, consult Congress, and work with other nations to hold accountable those involved in the killing of Jamal Khashoggi."

author: Sarah Zimmerman
title: Report points to 'difficult and worrying' 2019 for U.S. agriculture
description: Rabobank predicts trade woes and extreme weather could destabilize global food commodity prices next year.
content: The report noted that climate experts are forecasting an 80 percent chance of El Niño weather conditions being formally declared "by the end of the northern winter." | AP Photo Market volatility caused by President Donald Trump's trade disputes, extreme weath… [+4218 chars]
fulltext:
The downward trend of U.S. farmers' profitability will only get worse if China continues to ignore American agricultural imports, the report said. | Steve Helber/AP Photo Report points to 'difficult and worrying' 2019 for U.S. agriculture

Market volatility caused by President Donald Trump's trade disputes, extreme weather and the potential spread of African Swine Fever could threaten the stability of global food commodity prices next year, the agricultural banking company Rabobank warned Thursday in a new report.

“The agri-commodity price environment may be relatively stable currently, but it’s difficult to remember a time [when] there were so many threats to food commodity prices on so many fronts,” Stefan Vogel, Rabobank's head of agricultural commodity markets and a co-author of the report, said in a statement.

Story Continued Below

In Rabobank's annual Outlook report, the Holland-based company predicted that trade uncertainty remains the largest threat facing U.S. farmers next year. The downward trend of U.S. farmers' profitability will only get worse if China continues to ignore American agricultural imports, the report said. Fiscal 2018 marked the second-worst profitability year for American farmers in nearly the last decade, the report said, despite record-smashing corn and soybean yields and the fact that Chinese retaliatory tariffs only directly affected one-quarter of the 12-month period.

Rabobank anticipates that American soybean farmers will continue to take the biggest hit if Beijing keeps its tariffs in place — and that U.S. soybean stocks "will easily double" under that scenario. USDA Secretary Sonny Perdue has said that farmers will not receive additional trade aid for 2019 production, reasoning that Trump's tariff policies have already altered markets and that farmers must now react accordingly.

In many cases, that may be easier said than done. "These measures," the report said, referring to tit-for-tat tariffs, "change the structure of global trade and increase U.S. inventories to new all-time highs, while hurting U.S. farmer margins, and resulting in great uncertainty when it comes to prices and the upcoming 2019 planting season."

Agricultural producers should prepare for other factors beyond trade, according to the report. If African Swine Fever, which has cropped up in places in China's massive pork industry, spreads to become a full-on outbreak, consumer concern could lead to shifts in preferences, in turn affecting global trade flows.

In addition, the report noted that climate experts are forecasting an 80 percent chance of El Niño weather conditions being formally declared "by the end of the northern winter." El Niño-related weather patterns tend to make the U.S. Southern Plains wetter and can also lead to drier conditions in the northern part of the U.S. Midwest.

With El Niño-like effects already being experienced in parts of Australia, Brazil and India, the report said, further weather change holds the potential to hurt crop yields and production, and influence global trade in agricultural commodities.

“Food producers face a melting pot of risks,” Justin Sherrard, a global strategist for animal protein at Rabobank, said in a statement. “Although it’s possible that not all of them will come to pass, they need to be prepared for a difficult and worrying year in 2019.”

The report predicted a hefty surplus in U.S. soybeans next year and a global glut in coffee and, less significantly, in palm oil and sugar. It forecast global deficits in corn, wheat, cocoa and cotton, noting that hurricane-related damage affected the U.S. cotton crop this year.

With Trump expected to talk trade with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the end of the month, the report was not overly pessimistic about the possibility that the two economic superpowers could strike a deal to ease trade tension.

The report said it "may take very long negotiations" to address America's trade deficit with China "by any significant amount." However, Rabobank said it was "surprising" how quickly the new North American trade agreement came together and that "we can’t rule out a speedy resolution to the U.S.-China trade war."

"Once achieved," the report said of a U.S.-China trade deal, "it will likely result in China buying increasing quantities of American goods. Under a Chinese tariff regime, however, the U.S. will easily double its soybean stocks."

This article tagged under: Agriculture

title: Nelson intervenes in GOP ag commissioner candidate challenge to block Scott
description: Nelson's campaign and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee have intervened and presented a witness list for the hearing.
content: Nelson's campaign and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee have intervened and presented a witness list for the hearing. | AP Photo TALLAHASSEE The campaign of Sen. Bill Nelson (D-Fla.) says it is intervening in a vote-counting lawsuit filed by the Re… [+3171 chars]
fulltext:
Nelson's campaign and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee have intervened and presented a witness list for the hearing. | AP Photo Nelson intervenes in GOP ag commissioner candidate challenge to block Scott

TALLAHASSEE — The campaign of Sen. Bill Nelson (D-Fla.) says it is intervening in a vote-counting lawsuit filed by the Republican candidate for agriculture commissioner to block Gov. Rick Scott's efforts to obstruct vote counting.

Former state Rep. Matt Caldwell, the Republican candidate for agriculture commissioner, lost the lead to Democrat Nikki Fried two days after he declared victory on election night Nov. 6. She leads in the unofficial results by 5,326 votes, or 0.06 percent, as a machine recount is continuing.

Story Continued Below

Caldwell sued Nov. 9 and filed an amended complaint on Nov. 11 alleging past misconduct by Broward County Supervisor of Elections Brenda Snipes. A hearing is scheduled for 1 p.m. Thursday in circuit court in Fort Lauderdale on Caldwell’s emergency motion seeking public records from Snipes.

Nelson's campaign and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee have intervened and presented a witness list for the hearing. Nelson trails Scott in his own reelection by 12,562 votes as the two battle in court over ballot-counting in their race.

In a motion obtained Thursday by POLITICO, the Nelson campaign and committee say they were intervening to ensure that lawfully cast ballots are counted despite such efforts by Scott "and parities affiliated with him" to impede local vote counting, including false allegations of voter fraud. Those affiliated parties are not named.

"Intervenors seek to intervene here and participate in this matter to ensure that all lawfully cast ballots from eligible voters are counted, to guarantee that the recount process is not impeded or obstructed due to Governor Scott’s unfounded allegations, and to seek the immediate dismissal of this matter so as not to disturb or intentionally delay the work of the Broward County supervisor of elections," they wrote.

There was no immediate response from the Scott campaign. But Joe Jackson, deputy Florida communications director for the Republican National Committee, said Thursday in a press release, "Bill Nelson needs to understand that the people of Florida have spoken, and they have elected Rick Scott as their next Senator."

Caldwell campaign spokeswoman Danielle Alvarez said Thursday: “We want to ensure every legal vote is counted and that we have a forensic reconstruction to establish the source of more than 80,000 ballots that were counted after Election Day.

"Voters expect and deserve a straightforward explanation from the Broward County supervisor of elections that will help restore faith in the integrity of Florida's electoral process," she said.

Fried attorney Ben Kuehne said Wednesday that Caldwell's "false and specious" lawsuit "smacks of desperation."

“Florida law is clear — all Supervisors of Elections are legally obligated to count all the votes and certify the tabulation by the Saturday following the election," Kuehne said in a statement provided to POLITICO by the Fried campaign. "Any votes that were legally cast should count. Florida has no place for misleading complaints raised by losing candidates."

The Nelson campaign's and the DSCC's motion to intervene was filed Monday, but it is not listed on the docket in the Caldwell lawsuit on the Broward County clerk of court's website. The witness and exhibit lists do appear on the docket.

Senate Republicans were panned for bringing in a female outside counsel to question Dr. Christine Blasey Ford about sexual assault allegations leveled at Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh, since there were no GOP women on the Senate Judiciary Committee.

So now they are zeroing in on a name to change the panel’s gender imbalance: Marsha Blackburn.

Story Continued Below

The Tennessee Republican was just elected to the Senate and has become a favorite to join the committee, according to two people familiar with internal talks. Still, no final decision has been made, and the Senate is weeks away from determining committee slots.

Senate Republicans are eager to address their gender diversity issues.

Sen. Joni Ernst of Iowa was just elected to the leadership team — the first woman to hold a slot since 2010 — and leaders want a female senator on the Judiciary Committee. In previous years, it’s been difficult to convince female senators to join the panel, according to Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley.

In a brief interview on Thursday, Blackburn shrugged off questions about the panel.

author: coprysko@politico.com (Caitlin Oprysko)
title: McCarthy: 'It wasn't that much' the year of the woman for GOP
description: Republicans will work to increase diversity of their caucus, House leader says.
content: We have a lot of room to grow, House GOP leader Kevin McCarthy said, but he argued that we don't have a problem per se just with women." | Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images Newly reelected Republican leader Kevin McCarthy pledged that his party would work to recr… [+2412 chars]
fulltext:
“We have a lot of room to grow,” House GOP leader Kevin McCarthy said, but he argued that “we don't have a problem per se just with women." | Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images congress GOP leader concedes 'we have room for improvement' on House diversity

Newly reelected Republican leader Kevin McCarthy pledged Thursday that his party would work to recruit more diverse candidates in the next election cycle, on the heels of midterms that saw more women and minorities than ever elected to Congress, almost entirely from the Democratic Party.

McCarthy (R-Calif.) also acknowledged in an interview on “CBS This Morning” that the party could improve its overall standing with women after college-educated, suburban women proved to be a decisive bloc in putting Democrats back in control of the House. But the current House majority leader, who will be the minority leader when the new Congress is sworn in next year, said President Donald Trump's rhetoric was not to blame.

Story Continued Below

“We have a lot of room to grow,” McCarthy said, but he argued that “we don't have a problem per se just with women,” noting the historical trend of a sitting president’s party losing seats in midterm elections as well as the record number of GOP retirements in the House this year. The GOP leader also pointed out that a handful of female House Republicans ran for higher office this year.

“It was the year of the woman,” McCarthy said, referring to the crush of women who ran for office in 2018, though in the Republican Party, he conceded, “it wasn't that much.”

“We have room for improvement. If you look at, in the Democratic primaries where there was an open seat and it was a woman versus a man, a woman won 69 percent of the time. So of course they had more women coming forward. We can do better in recruitment, and that's what I'm excited about doing,” he said.

Sign up here for POLITICO Huddle A daily play-by-play of congressional news in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Among called House races, Republicans elected only one new female House member, Rep.-elect Carol Miller (R-W.Va.), compared to 34 for Democrats. Flyers circulated at the Capitol for new member orientation this week show the stark contrast between the diversity of incoming Democratic House members and the class of GOP newcomers, who are overwhelmingly white and male.

McCarthy on Thursday said Republicans had diverse candidates who were defeated in the midterms and offered up two newly elected military veterans, both white men, as a show of diversity in Republicans’ incoming class.

“We're diverse, but we can continue to expand and improve,” he said.

author: soverly@politico.com (Steven Overly)
title: Facebook fires consultants following damning New York Times report
description: The Times report described Facebook as hiring consultants who spread negative stories about rivals and questioned its critics' funding.
content: In a statement published early Thursday, Facebook denied that political communications firm Definers was asked to produce articles on its behalf. | AP Photo/Martin Meissner Facebook has terminated its contract with political communications firm Definers Publi… [+1872 chars]
fulltext:
Part of the New York Times' exposé revealed that Facebook hired a PR firm that circulated a document to journalists portraying some of Facebook's critics as pawns of liberal philanthropist George Soros, a tactic that appears to exploit anti-Semitic conspiracy theories. | POLITICO illustration/iStock Images Technology Facebook reconsiders Washington approach after Times reveals hardball tactics

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg vowed to cut ties with "D.C.-type firms" as his company fought to escape yet another bout of furor, this time surrounding its efforts to contain the damage from Russian election interference and consumer privacy violations.

A New York Times exposé published Wednesday reveals that Facebook’s efforts to defend its reputation included the hiring of a public relations firm that circulated a document to journalists portraying some of Facebook's critics as pawns of liberal philanthropist George Soros, a tactic that appears to exploit anti-Semitic conspiracy theories.

Story Continued Below

“This type of firm might be normal in Washington but it’s not the kind of thing I want Facebook associated with," Zuckerberg said in a call with reporters Thursday. He added that neither he nor Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg, a central figure in the Times story, knew about the firm’s work for Facebook until reading the newspaper’s report.

The Times said Facebook also recruited support from powerful friends in Washington, such as Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.), to tamp down talk of regulation that could hamper its business. And it went to pains to seek favor with conservatives — for example by declining to penalize then-candidate Donald Trump’s attacks on Muslims in late 2015. The company said Trump's comments got a pass for newsworthiness, the same explanation Twitter has offered for allowing posts from the president that appear to violate platform rules.

Morning Tech Technology news from Washington and Silicon Valley — weekday mornings, in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Other major corporations routinely employ hardball tactics and curry favor with power brokers. But the revelations strike another blow to an already embattled Facebook, which has scrambled to fend off criticism that it failed to address its role as a potential vector for social ills like misinformation, foreign election interference, terrorism and human rights abuses.

Zuckerberg said Thursday that the company will review it ties to outside consultants. Earlier the same day, the company announced it was terminating its contract with political communications firm Definers Public Affairs, which the Times identified as one of the key consultants that spread negative stories about rivals like Google and Apple and questioned critics' funding sources.

Zuckerberg pledged an internal review of all outside firms Facebook works with, to be led by Nick Clegg, the former UK deputy prime minister Facebook recently tapped to lead its policy and communications teams.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said Thursday that the company will review it ties to outside consultants after criticism over tactics revealed in the Times' story. | John Shinkle/POLITICO

The press call, ostensibly held as a briefing on Facebook's efforts to improve its content moderation practices, became a bid for damage control after the report drew attention to the roles of Zuckerberg and, more critically, Sandberg — a bestselling author who was once seen as a potential Cabinet member for Hillary Clinton.

Patrick Gaspard, president of the Soros-founded Open Society Foundations, said in a letter to Sandberg late Wednesday that he was "astonished" by the Times report.

"It's been disappointing to see how you have failed to monitor hate and misinformation on Facebook's platform," wrote Gaspard, whose group is the principal vehicle for Soros' donations. "To now learn that you are active in promoting these distortions is beyond the pale."

According to the Times’ report, the product of a six-month investigation, Sandberg and other Facebook executives deliberately slow-walked the company's response to Russian manipulation and other politically fraught abuses of the platform to avoid seeming to favor Democrats. Zuckerberg said on the call that Facebook was "too slow to spot Russian interference" but that it was "simply untrue" that delay was intentional. He did not deny that, as the world learned of those interference campaigns, Facebook under Sandberg's leadership turned to third-party firms to do battle with the company's detractors.

As illustrated in documents obtained by POLITICO, consultants and company allies depicted critics of Facebook and its leadership as anti-Semitic (Sandberg and Zuckerberg are both Jewish). And they tried to get media outlets to report on financial ties between Facebook foes and Soros, itself a tactic echoing longstanding anti-Semitic conspiracy theories about Jewish financiers shaping world events.

Facebook on Thursday denied that Definers was asked to produce articles on its behalf. Instead, Facebook said Definers was used to contact journalists about "important press calls" and to investigate funding behind its critics at the organization "Freedom from Facebook."

"The intention was to demonstrate that it was not simply a spontaneous grassroots campaign, as it claimed, but supported by a well-known critic of our company," the Facebook statement said. "To suggest that this was an anti-Semitic attack is reprehensible and untrue."

A Definers spokesperson said the research it conducted for Facebook "was entirely factual and based on public records, including public statements by one of its organizers about receiving funding from Mr. Soros' foundation."

The Times report comes as Facebook is already looking to blunt the prospects of a regulatory crackdown, tough new legislation targeting Silicon Valley business practices around issues like privacy — or both.

Lawmakers told POLITICO Thursday they were troubled by the Times story.

“It’s alarming. It’s appalling. They just have to be held to account” said Hawaii Sen. Brian Schatz, a high-ranking and influential Democrat on the Commerce Committee. “That doesn’t sound like a neutral platform to me. That sounds like a major corporation using its financial weight and its political clout to advance its own interests.”

Schatz said he plans in the wake of the report to meet with Commerce Chairman John Thune (R-S.D.) to continue discussions on crafting privacy legislation that could add substantial federal oversight to Facebook's handling of user data.

The report also caught the attention of Sen. Mark Warner (D-Va.), a leading critic of Facebook and other internet companies from his perch as top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee. According to the Times report, Schumer, whose daughter works at Facebook, told Warner to ensure his actions don't hurt the company.

Warner declined to comment on any talks with Schumer. He did, however, pledge to "continue to pursue this," telling POLITICO, "The fact that it literally took months and months of relentless activity to take this issue seriously ... is a problem."

Schumer spokesman Justin Goodman would not confirm or deny his intervention on Facebook's behalf, but defended the senator as trying to "push Facebook to do more to purge fake accounts and bots used by the right wing and Russians to perpetuate a disinformation campaign and interfere with our elections."

Schumer has "urged Senator Warner and the Senate Intelligence committee to make this the priority in their ongoing investigation of the company," Goodman said.

In concert with the congressional scrutiny, federal investigators are probing Facebook over some of the issues that sparked the damage-control efforts in the first place. The Federal Trade Commission announced in March it would investigate the social media giant's failure to secure the data of millions of users against improper access by Cambridge Analytica, a political consulting firm connected to Trump's 2016 campaign.

Matt Stoller, policy director at Open Markets Institute, one of the groups Definers targeted, told POLITICO that the FTC needs to punish Facebook and set rules to rein in the company's behavior.

"If they don’t do anything meaningful, then Congress needs to step in and do something," he added. "Facebook is perfectly willing to engage in tactics that reflect a total disrespect for any ethical grounding whatsoever.

"If the legal context were different, they would have to act differently," Stoller said.

Nancy Scola contributed to this report.

DOWNHILL FROM HERE? Our Ben White looks at why the economy right now may be as good as it’s going to get, and what that means for Republicans. “Fiscal stimulus from the GOP tax cuts is likely to start running out. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep bumping up interest rates. And few analysts expect a divided Congress — facing soaring deficits and with its eyes on 2020 — to join hands and pass a big infrastructure package or sweeping middle-class tax cuts to keep the fiscal juice going.” That, along with President Donald Trump’s trade wars, he says, “could deny Trump the kind of big economic growth numbers he loves to celebrate. And they could undercut one of the GOP’s biggest current arguments: You may not love what Trump says or does, but the Trump economy is awesome.”

IT’S THURSDAY. Tell us what we should be writing about. We’re at bfaler@politico.com, alorenzo@politico.com teckert@politico.com and bbecker@politico.com. You can also find us Twittering at @berniebecker3, @tobyeckert, @brianfaler, @aaronelorenzo, and, of course, at @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Tax.

ABOUT THOSE AMAZON SUBSIDIES… Our Steven Overly looks at how big incentive packages politicians put together to lure companies can go wrong, focusing on Wisconsin’s deal to bring Foxconn to the Badger State. Once touted as a triumph for Gov. Scott Walker, opinion shifted amid “tax breaks, regulatory rollbacks and other favors that Wisconsin was handing Foxconn. The cost of the state incentives continued to climb while the size of the factory and number of new jobs appeared to be shrinking — a reality that may have contributed to Walker’s ouster at the polls last week,” he says.

The New York Times, meanwhile, wonders how much those incentives even matter. “In selecting New York and Virginia for its new locations, Amazon turned down seemingly richer offers just next door. Maryland and New Jersey each offered multi-billion dollar incentive packages that dwarfed the ones Amazon accepted,” the New York Times reports. “Gov. Andrew Cuomo defended the deal, arguing New York has to offer incentives because of its comparatively high taxes,“ the paper said. “If we do nothing, they’re going to Texas,” said Cuomo.

THE OPPORTUNITY ZONE CONNECTION: Much of the New York site Amazon selected for a new headquarters is eligible for the new “Opportunity Zone” program offering tax breaks for investing in underdeveloped areas, the Associated Press reports. “Critics question whether Long Island City, the fast-gentrifying Queens neighborhood across the East River from the skyscrapers of midtown Manhattan, needs such breaks. Median household income around Amazon’s planned campus is $130,000, poverty is half the city average and new buildings were going up long before the overhaul.”

Politics

MACARTHUR LOSES: Rep. Tom MacArthur, the only New Jersey lawmaker to back the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, lost his reelection bid thanks in part to the law’s cap on state and local tax deductions. The loss “caps a devastating midterm election for Republicans in New Jersey,” the New York Times reports. “With 11 Democrats now holding House seats, Representative Chris Smith is the lone Republican in Washington from New Jersey; the last time Democrats had such a large advantage Theodore Roosevelt was in the Oval Office.”

HARRIS’ TAX CUT IS EVEN BIGGER THAN TRUMP’S: Potential 2020 Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris’ tax cut plan weighs in at $2.8 trillion, the Tax Policy Center says, or almost twice what the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act costs. All that debt is a big reason why TPC says the plan would actually hurt the economy in the long run. But it would provide a big benefit to average Americans — those in the bottom quintile of incomes would see their after-tax earnings climb 12.6 percent.

IRS

THE IRS NEEDS HELP WITH WEED MONEY: The agency is paying $1.7 million to an outside firm to help it process tax payments in cash from marijuana producers, Quartz reports. Many weed sellers are unbanked because financial institutions don’t want to deal with them, so they pay their taxes in cash.

Says Quartz: “When a cannabis business pays federal taxes, someone has to schedule an appointment with the IRS to go to its local offices and make a cash deposit. A secure space is set aside to count it all, and there are two IRS employees inside the room at all times, explained Oakland cannabis accountant Luigi Zamarra.” Quartz dug up data showing the IRS paying Virginia-based Mitre Corporation for “large cash payments for processing cannabis federal taxes.” Both declined comment.

AMID LEAN BUDGETS, IRS TURNS TO DATA ANALYTICS: “IRS criminal investigations increasingly rely on data analytics as the number of agents has waned at that division of the agency,” our Aaron Lorenzo reports. The number of special agents has fallen to a 40-year low “due to retirements and a lack of hiring over the past five years due to lean IRS budgets.” The agency is “increasingly making use of data-based models, algorithms and existing records and evidence,” Lorenzo reports.

STATE NEWS

CHICAGO IS TAXING YOUR PLAYSTATION: “Playstation users in Chicago on Wednesday began paying a 9 percent tax on streaming content as the gaming company starts complying with a city levy,” the Chicago Tribune reports. “The city’s amusement tax, which used to apply mostly to concert and sporting event tickets, was extended to include streaming services in 2015. That includes charges paid for playing games, according to Chicago’s Finance Department. Some tech companies have fought the additional 9 percent charge. Apple filed a lawsuit against the city in August alleging the tax on its music streaming services was illegal and discriminatory.”

SYRACUSE TRIES IT THE EASY WAY: “A city in New York state has found a novel way of motivating residents to pay their back taxes: personal notes handwritten by city officials,” the Associated Press says. “City officials wrote and signed thousands of notes by hand, rather than sending standard legal letters demanding payment. The result was the city collecting nearly $1.5 million more than it predicted.”

ANCHORAGE CONSIDERS ALCOHOL TAX HIKE: The city’s mayor wants to raise taxes to help fund substance abuse and anti-homelessness programs. “Alcohol is an incredibly profitable business in this town,” said Mayor Ethan Berkowitz, the Anchorage Daily News reports. The tax would add 40 cents to the cost of a six-pack of beer, the paper says. Congress slashed taxes on alcohol makers as part of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, to the consternation of public-health advocates.

INTERNATIONAL UPDATE

JAPAN & THE ART OF RAISING TAXES: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe wants to raise the country’s sale tax, “which the government has done twice since It was introduced in 1989” and “has sent the economy into reverse and incited political revolts,” Bloomberg Businessweek reports. “But with the ruling party recently reaffirming its support for his leadership, he’s seized on next year as the best time to bolster the government’s revenue base without tipping the economy into recession. The construction boom for the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo is set to roll on, exports look likely to hold up, and the gross domestic product is forecast to expand by just more than one percent – a healthy number by Japanese standards.”

QUICK LINKS

The Tax Policy Center’s Renu Zaretsky on why tax-free tampons are a bad idea

ITEP on repealing the SALT cap

How many income tax brackets does your state have?

DID YOU KNOW?

The person who donated the Hope Diamond to the Smithsonian send it to the museum through the mail.

USMCA on the docket

With help from Sabrina Rodriguez

Editor’s Note: This edition of Morning Trade is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Trade subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro’s comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Trade will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22, and Friday, Nov. 23. Our next newsletter will publish on Monday, Nov. 26. Please continue to follow Pro Trade issues here.

ON TAP TODAY: It’s a big day for NAFTA 2.0 today as dozens of industry officials and others gather at the U.S. International Trade Commission to share their thoughts on the new agreement. European trade czar Cecilia Malmström’s visit to Washington is wrapping up with little clarity on the future of U.S.-EU trade talks — but plenty of warnings from Brussels about retaliation against car tariffs and how it doesn’t want to touch agriculture. Plus, the most influential figure at this week’s Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperationleaders summit might be the one who’s not there: Donald Trump. Let’s start here:

SOUNDING OFF ON USMCA: Dozens of industry representatives, labor groups and lawmakers are headed to the U.S. International Trade Commission today and Friday to make their case either for or against NAFTA’s new replacement.

The hearing is part of an ITC probe examining the effect of the new U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement on the broader U.S. economy as well as individual sectors. That investigation, which is required under Trade Promotion Authority, will wrap up with a report due by mid-March, though it could potentially conclude sooner. Congress is expected to wait until the ITC report is complete to vote on the USMCA, though it is not legally required to do so.

Voicing their views: The hearing will start off with testimony from Democratic Reps. Sander Levin, who is retiring at the end of the year, and Bill Pascrell, whose potential role as the incoming chairman of the House Ways and Means Trade Subcommittee means that his support for the deal could be crucial to its passage in the Democrat-controlled House.

Auto group representatives are then scheduled to kick off the first of what will be six panels over two days, which are more or less divided by industry. Agriculture groups will also testify Thursday. They will be followed by labor and environmental groups whose stance on the deal could prove influential among newly powerful House Democrats.

The steel elephant in the room: Throughout six panels worth of testimonies that will run through Friday, expect substantial commentary on the need for the Trump administration to remove steel and aluminum tariffs on Canada and Mexico in order for the new deal to prove effective.

“The new USMCA simply cannot work as intended for the aluminum industry and our customers with those tariffs — or quotas to limit access to supply — in place,” Heidi Brock of the Aluminum Association wrote.

Or, as the Beer Institute, put it: “We do not believe the agreement is complete, however, unless steel and aluminum tariffs are completely eliminated. And for the record — we don’t support quotas in lieu of tariffs.”

IT'S THURSDAY, NOV. 15! Welcome to Morning Trade, where your host decided last night to try the popular internet prank where millennials text their parents asking how long they should microwave a 25 pound turkey for and is still laughing at the results. Any suggestions out there for what crazy thing I should text my mom today? Let me know: mcassella@politico.com or @mmcassella.

MALMSTRӦM PLEDGES TIT FOR TAT: The European Union will waste no time in retaliating against the U.S. if the Trump administration moves forward with import duties on European cars. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström said Wednesday in Washington that she has a “draft list” of products “covering lots of different sectors” that would face penalties if Trump hits the EU auto industry first. But she also said she did not discuss the issue during her meeting with U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer. Doug has more.

All-important agriculture: Malmström warned that any prospective trade talks would likely come to a standstill if the Trump administration continues to push for agriculture to be included as part of any deal — including if it even lists ag among its negotiating objectives it is expected to send to Congress before talks begin.

"I understand that it is still important from the U.S. side, but we have been very clear that it is not going to be in a trade agreement from our side," Malmström told reporters. "Things haven’t changed." More on that here.

U.K. CABINET BACKS DRAFT BREXIT DEAL: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Wednesday won the support of her Cabinet on the draft Brexit withdrawal agreement after a “long, detailed and impassioned debate.”

Under the draft agreement, the U.K. and EU will aim to have a trade deal wrapped up before the end of the transition period in December 2020, but that could be extended if there’s no deal by then.

What’s next: Securing the “collective decision” of her Cabinet without any immediate resignations makes room for a summit with European Union leaders in Brussels that has been penciled in for Nov. 25.

Tougher parts to come: The prime minister for now dodges a damaging no-deal Brexit, but the stage is still set for a much larger battle to get her deal through parliament. May acknowledged there would be “difficult” days ahead and “intense scrutiny” of her draft deal.

U.S. connection: Rep. Ron Kind (D-Wis.) on Wednesday raised concern about the “catastrophic consequences that can flow from a bad Brexit.”

“For many, many years, we’ve relied on Great Britain, especially, to carry our water in EU negotiations. We’re not going to have that when it comes to their exit from the EU, so we’re going to have to find new avenues of relevancy within the EU,” Kind, a senior member of the House Ways and Means Committee, told Morning Trade. More on the deal here.

WARNINGS REACTIVATED OVER AUTO TARIFFS: Reports this week that a draft of the administration’s Section 232 report on auto imports is undergoing the interagency review process have led to a fresh wave of criticism over the threat to impose new tariffs on cars.

Where it would hurt: The Tax Foundation put out a new analysis Wednesday estimating that blanket 25 percent tariffs on all imports could cause a $53.1 billion economic hit and lead to the loss of more than 164,000 jobs.

They also mapped out what the impact would be divvied up by individual trading partner. If Canada and Mexico are excluded, for example, those numbers drop to nearly $28 billion and 86,000 jobs. More here.

The Organization for International Investment also added its voice, noting that the effects of imposing “bygone industrial policy in the automotive sector under the pretext of national security” would likely “creep into every corner of our economy.” The statement came out alongside a new OFII survey showing that chief financial officers list potential auto tariffs as the largest threat to U.S. competitiveness.

TRUMP LOOMS LARGE OVER PENCE’S ASIA TRIP: Trump may have chosen to skip this year’s Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit taking place in Papua New Guinea this weekend, but that doesn’t mean his presence won’t be felt.

“In the background, we’ve got big trade frictions going on and that’s definitely hung over the agenda,” Alan Bollard, executive director of the APEC secretariat, told Morning Trade. “There are some differences in terms of the terms of trade.”

In his place: Vice President Mike Pence will attend APEC and meet with leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations this week in Trump’s stead. Lighthizer is expected to attend, Bollard said, though USTR has yet to make any formal announcement.

STEELWORKERS GET A POST-TARIFF RAISE: The United Steelworkers signed a new contract this week that secures a 14 percent increase in wages over the next four years and strengthens retirement benefits, changes the union and Trump administration officials both said were a result of profits the industry has begun to see since steel import tariffs took effect earlier this year.

Trump takes credit: “Not seen in many years, America’s steelworkers get a hard-earned raise because of my Administration’s policies to help bring back the U.S. steel industry, which is critical to our National Security,” Trump tweeted Wednesday afternoon. “I will always protect America and its workers!” Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross chimed in with his own statement saying that the new contract illustrates the “wisdom” of the president’s trade policies.

NEW SANCTIONS ON CUBA GO INTO EFFECT TODAY: The State Department released on Wednesday a list of more than two dozen Cuban companies that will begin to face sanctions today. Americans are barred from any financial dealings with the companies, which have ties to the Communist-run island’s military and intelligence services.

The Trump administration first placed sanctions on almost 200 Cuban entities in November, as part of an effort to walk back on some of former President Barack Obama’s pro-engagement policies. White House National Security Adviser John Bolton first announced that there would be more sanctions on Cuba earlier this month.

Pushback: James Williams, president of Engage Cuba, a coalition that supports normalized relations, said the new sanctions are part of an “attempt to choke commercial ties with Cuba” and “play into the hands of adversaries like the Chinese government and Vladimir Putin, both of which are actively trying to undermine U.S. interests in Latin America.”

TRADE REMEDY CORNER

CHINESE RUBBER BANDS EDITION: The Commerce Department found evidence that rubber bands from China are being unfairly subsidized and dumped in the United States. In its final ruling, the agency moved to impose anti-dumping duties of 27.3 percent and anti-subsidy duties of 125.8 percent on imports of the product from China, which were valued at an estimated $4.9 million last year. The case now moves to the ITC, which is scheduled to make its final determinations on or around Dec. 28.

INTERNATIONAL OVERNIGHT

— Ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting, China has provided a written response to the Trump administration’s trade demands, Reuters reports.

— As fiscal stimulus from this year’s tax cuts wear off and a divided Congress takes control of Washington next year, the economy’s recent sugar high is likely to wear off, POLITICO Pro reports.

— The difference between U.S. export prices for soybeans and Brazilian exports is narrowing, indicating the industry could be seeing signs of progress in U.S.-China trade relations, CNBC reports.

— Rep. Bill Pascrell says the USMCA must change in order to pass Congress, Bloomberg reports.

THAT'S ALL FOR MORNING TRADE! See you again soon! In the meantime, drop the team a line: abehsudi@politico.com and @abehsudi; mcassella@politico.com and @mmcassella; dpalmer@politico.com and @tradereporter; srodriguez@politico.com and @sabrod123; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny. Also follow us @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Trade.

NTSB advances Southwest fatality investigation with hearing

With help from Brianna Gurciullo, Stephanie Beasley, Tanya Snyder and Alex Guillén

Editor’s Note: This edition of Morning Transportation is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Transportation subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro’s comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Transportation will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22, and Friday, Nov. 23. Our next Morning Transportation newsletter will publish on Monday, Nov. 26. Please continue to follow Transportation issues here.

NTSB DIGS INTO SOUTHWEST 1380: The agency held a hearing Wednesday about the failure of an engine on a Southwest Airlines flight earlier this year, with representatives from Boeing, FAA, the airline and engine manufacturer CFM International testifying. During the April incident, a fan blade detached and debris crashed into the fuselage. The plane lost one window and a passenger, Jennifer Riordan, was partly sucked out. A medical examiner later found that Riordan died from “blunt force trauma.”

Piece by piece: Participants in the daylong hearing spoke about the fan blades as well as other parts of CFM56-7 engines. NTSB member T. Bella Dinh-Zarr noted at the end of the hearing that it’ll be months before a final report about the accident is ready.

Scary, to say the least: NTSB on Wednesday also made available the docket for its investigation. According to an interview summary, a flight attendant said she saw Riordan in her seat with her upper torso, head and arms outside the plane. The attendant took hold of Riordan’s leg and another held her lower body. A pair of male passengers came to help pull her inside. The flight attendant also noted that during the flight, “many oxygen masks were broken and pulled down to the point the air hose was not attached,” and many passengers “had it on over their mouth and not their nose.”

Communication difficulties: Meanwhile, in the cockpit, first officer Darren Ellisor said it was so noisy that it was difficult at first to communicate with air traffic control and Capt. Tammie Jo Shults, who eventually landed the plane at Philadelphia International Airport. Ellisor said that their oxygen masks, the so-called startle factor and the “temporary loss of situational awareness” also played a role in the communication problems. As the plane was descending, he tried to call the flight attendants. Eventually, he got in touch with one, who told him “there was someone outside the aircraft,” according to an interview summary. After the plane was on the ground, the pilots had trouble communicating with fire trucks via radio.

IT’S THURSDAY: Thanks for tuning in to POLITICO’s Morning Transportation, your daily tipsheet on all things trains, planes, automobiles and ports. Get in touch with feedback, tips or song lyric suggestions at smintz@politico.com or @samjmintz.

“I drive a beat-up car, a caravan, the color blue / Reminds me of your eyes and all the places we've been to / We're tethered to the leather, searching for a better view / It's interstellar when it's me and you”

LISTEN HERE: Follow MT’s playlist on Spotify. What better way to start your day than with songs (picked by us and readers) about roads, rails, rivers and runways?

** A message from PlanetM – Michigan, where big ideas in mobility are born: When it comes to mobility, safety is no accident in Michigan. Recently named a federal driverless car proving ground, Michigan’s American Center for Mobility offers real world testing environments to validate self-driving systems. Learn how public-private ventures are helping Michigan create a safer world. Visit PlanetM.com **

FULL SPEED AHEAD: A Coast Guard reauthorization (S. 140 (115)) passed the Senate with fairly broad support Wednesday. The handful of dissenters included Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and Sens. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), Ben Cardin (D-Md.), Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), and Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.). The bill will now move to the House, which passed similar reauthorization language in a defense bill earlier (H.R. 5515 (115)) this year.

FIRST IN MT: BIPARTISAN BILL WOULD REFORM TIFIA LOANS: Sens. John Cornyn (R-Texas) and Tim Kaine (D-Va.) plan to introduce a bill today aimed at reforming DOT's TIFIA loans. The legislation would expedite projects that meet certain specifications and require DOT to publish status reports online. And it would raise the threshold for projects that need to secure two opinions from credit rating agencies from $75 million to $150 million. "These carefully targeted changes will make it easier, faster, and more cost effective for communities to finance key transportation projects with TIFIA loans, while also maintaining rigorous loan standards," Kaine said in a statement.

COMMITTEE LEADERSHIP CHANGES: Commerce Chairman John Thune (R-S.D.) was officially elected to the position of majority whip on Wednesday, cementing a long-expected promotion. He will have to abandon his gavel, meaning the top spot on Commerce is set to go to Sen. Roger Wicker (R-Miss.), who is next in line in seniority.

Only one remains: On the House side, Rep. Sam Graves (R-Mo.) is in line to be ranking member of the Transportation Committee, after Rep. Jeff Denham (R-Calif.) officially lost his reelection bid earlier this week. In an October interview, Graves told MT that his experience serving in the minority would be helpful as ranking member — he’s one of only two Republican members on the committee who have done so (the other is Alaska’s Don Young). Graves has also been a ranking member before, on the Small Business Committee. “I know how to work with members on both sides of the aisle. That’s how you get things done. [Incoming Chairman Peter DeFazio] and I have a great relationship,” he said. “As I did with Nydia Velázquez on Small Business, we couldn’t be further apart, two different polar opposites when it comes to politics, but we were able to get a lot of stuff done. And it would be the same way with Peter.”

Subcommittee shuffle: We’re still polling members to see who’s interested in what subcommittee, and here’s the latest: Neither Rep. André Carson (D-Ind.) nor Rep. Albio Sires (D-N.J.) were interested in heading up the railroads subpanel. Sires said he’d defer to Donald Milford Payne, who is interested. Rep. Brian J. Mast (R-Fla.) wants to stay on as ranking member on the Coast Guard Subcommittee — "if they'll have me" — and expected Rep. John Garamendi (D-Calif.) would be chairman. Mast said they’d continue working on getting more icebreakers.

Infrastructure

IT’S NOT EASY FINDING GREEN: Senate leaders presented at-odds visions for Congress’ work on an infrastructure package Wednesday, your host reports. Schumer reiterated that Democrats will push for a “real” bill with “direct and robust federal investments.” But Majority Leader Mitch McConnell warned “there’s no easy way to pay for infrastructure without impacting an awful lot of Americans,” despite saying that he hoped the two parties could work together on infrastructure. He said Republicans are not interested in a $900 billion stimulus package “which we did at the beginning of the Obama era.”

Airlines fear second attempt at tax increase: Meanwhile, airlines are bracing for the possibility that lawmakers, most likely in the House, could try to include ticket fee and tax increases in an infrastructure bill, after failing to attach such provisions to the FAA reauthorization. "Constitutionally, tax increases have to originate in the House and my suspicion is that an infrastructure package, which is a place where we might see that, is something that will also begin in the House,” said Sharon Pinkerton of Airlines for America. Stephanie Beasley has more details for Pros.

Rail

PTC GUT CHECK: Commuter railroads made progress on implementing positive train control in the third quarter of this year, and the American Public Transportation Association said it has “every expectation” that all 28 around the country will meet a Dec. 31 deadline. “Sixty-eight percent of the 28 commuter railroads are either in PTC operation, testing the technology on trains that operate regular passenger service, or awaiting FRA approval to begin such testing, the group told reporters,” Tanya reported for Pros.

Tightening their belts: Jim Derwinski, CEO and executive director of Chicago’s Metra, said his agency has had to forgo purchases of new locomotives and coach cars as well as other enhancements to pay for PTC. APTA President and CEO Paul Skoutelas said that as far as he knows, no railroads have raised fares explicitly to pay for PTC improvements.

On the Hill: Lawmakers are preparing to continue their oversight of PTC implementation. “I've been getting briefed and we’ll be addressing that with the administration probably in early December when we come back. Deadlines are deadlines," DeFazio told MT.

AUTOMOBILES

EPA EXEMPTS AUTO DEALERS FROM TAKATA RCRA REQUIREMENTS: EPA on Wednesday said it will exempt auto dealerships, collision shops and salvage yards that are pulling defective Takata airbags out of vehicles from hazardous waste management rules under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act. Until earlier this year, the defective inflators were all sent to Takata warehouses under a DOT order and were not subject to RCRA waste handling requirements. But Takata's bankruptcy and a change in DOT's order means the recalled inflators, which are subject to RCRA because of their propellant, can now be sent directly to special disposal facilities.

Streamlining the process: Many of the dealers and salvage yards pulling the airbags may not have the expertise or experience to meet more rigorous RCRA requirements, and that could lead to a slowdown in removing the dangerous airbags from cars still on the road, EPA said. The exemption will apply to all airbag waste, not just Takata, to "avoid confusion, increase efficiency and will help prevent non-Takata airbag waste from being diverted into the municipal waste stream," EPA said. The parts still must be sent to a RCRA-certified facility for ultimate disposal. The exemption will take effect as soon as the interim final rule is published in the Federal Register. EPA will also take public comment for 60 days with plans to formally finalize the rule next year.

NOMINATIONS

TWO TAPPED FOR MARITIME BOARD: Trump nominated Daniel Maffei and L.E. Sola to be members of the Federal Maritime Commission. Maffei, a former Congressman from New York, previously served a two-year term on the commission under President Barack Obama, but was not initially reappointed to the board by Trump when his term expired earlier this year. Sola is a member of the Florida Board of Pilot Commissioners.

THE AUTOBAHN

— “Volkswagen to devote 3 German plants to electric car push.” AP.

— “Qantas non-stop Sydney-London flight on the brink of ‘commercial viability’, a threat to Cathay Pacific and Hong Kong airport.” South China Morning Post.

— “Potomac Yard Metro entrance to be restored as part of Amazon deal.” WTOP.

— “Tales from the impending L-Train apocalypse.” New York Magazine.

— “BMW, Vodafone, Ericsson urge EU to consider 5G car standard.” Reuters.

— “Ford teaming up with Walmart and Postmates on robot deliveries.” The Verge.

— “The tragedy of Goodyear’s allegedly defective G159 tire keeps getting worse.” Jalopnik.

THE COUNTDOWN

DOT appropriations run out in 23 days. The FAA reauthorization expires in 1,780 days. Highway and transit policy is up for renewal in 686 days.

fulltext:
President Donald Trump's approval rating is at 43.2 percent, according to the RealClearPolitics polling average, which takes the average of nine major polls. | AP Photo/Andrew Harnik White House Trump says decreasing media favorability is a 'great achievement' of his presidency

Donald Trump said Wednesday that one of his great achievements as president is lowering the media's favorability among Americans, claiming a victory in his crusade against what he considers unfair press coverage at the same time that CNN is suing his administration to restore one of its reporter's revoked White House credentials.

The president, in an interview with the Daily Caller on Wednesday, said he believes Americans are starting to see many media outlets — Trump named CNN, ABC, CBS and NBC — as "fake news."

Story Continued Below

"You look at what’s going on with the fake news and the people get it," the president said. "And you know, they had a very high approval rating before I became president and I think it’s actually a great achievement of mine."

"Their approval rating now is down as low as just about anybody," the president continued.

The president has long had a contentious relationship with media, often labeling press coverage he does not like as "fake news." Egged on by the president, supporters at Trump's rallies also heckle reporters, sometimes chanting "CNN sucks." Trump also argued at a press conference last week with CNN‘s Jim Acosta, refusing to answer the reporter's questions in an exchange that prompted the administration to revoke Acosta's press credentials. CNN has since filed a lawsuit against the president and other top White House officials to have those credentials returned.

poster="http://v.politico.com/images/1155968404/201811/3411/1155968404_5858951556001_5858950724001-vs.jpg?pubId=1155968404" true

Fifty-five percent of Americans trust national news networks, according to a Poynter Media Trust Survey released in August. In regards to national newspapers, 59 percent trust them, with 47 percent trusting online-only organizations.

Trump also claimed that media approval rating is "much lower than your president."

The president's approval rating is at 43.2 percent, according to the RealClearPolitics polling average, which takes the average of nine major polls. That same polling average showed a 52.9 percent disapproval of Trump's handling of the presidency.

"I actually have good approval ratings, which nobody ever writes," he said.
