description: New supply chain security group meets today — DoD too slow adopting new tech, experts say
content: With help from Eric Geller, Martin Matishak and Christian Vasquez Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Cybersecurity is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Cybersecurity subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6… [+10370 chars]
fulltext:
What’s next for DHS cyber changeup

With help from Eric Geller, Martin Matishak and Christian Vasquez

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Cybersecurity is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Cybersecurity subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Cybersecurity will not publish Nov. 22 and Nov. 23. The newsletter will resume publishing on Nov. 26.

NEW NAME, SAME GREAT TASTE — President Donald Trump’s expected signature on a bill (H.R. 3359) renaming and reorganizing the DHS cyber wing will give that part of the department a much-needed boost in stature and begin a process of streamlining its operations, according to its leader. “It puts us on the level of other operational agencies within the federal government, including within the department,” Chris Krebs, the undersecretary in charge of the cyber wing, said at a National Security Telecommunications Advisory Committee meeting on Wednesday. He told reporters after the meeting that the bill “puts us into position to be the lead federal civilian cybersecurity agency,” where “right now, it’s not imminently clear” who has that role.

Once Trump signs the bill into law, it will rename the National Protection and Programs Directorate to the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency. But that is only the beginning, said Krebs, who described the change as “a groundbreaking, not a ribbon-cutting.” “We have a lot of work ahead of us,” he said. “Organizationally, I kind of equate us to a 14-year-old startup. We don’t have mature processes in place. We’ve got a lot of internal work to do. But we have a very clear sense of purpose.”

Krebs’ agency will follow the mantra of “defend today and secure tomorrow,” he told the NSTAC. In addition to its existing work protecting federal networks, DHS will “expand into the industrial control system area,” he said. It has already launched pilot programs in areas like pipeline cybersecurity. Industry help will be crucial in building a “collective defense model,” he said, because the federal government won’t be able to fill all of its cyber job openings. And DHS will lean heavily on guidance from the private sector rather than charging out with ideas developed entirely in-house. “I need my stakeholders to tell us what they need us to do,” he said.

In addition to industry collaboration, DHS will also place more emphasis on promoting public awareness of cyber issues. “What can we do to better educate the American public on cybersecurity risks and what they can do to protect themselves?” Krebs said, before praising the U.K. for its approach to the challenge.

FRABJOUS DAY, CALLOOH, CALLAY — Everybody’s pretty thrilled to see the CISA legislation finally get to the finish line. House Speaker Paul Ryan and sponsor Mike McCaul held a signing ceremony in honor of the occasion Wednesday. “The creation of CISA within the department is a long overdue step that will strengthen DHS’s ability to execute its cyber mission and enhance coordination among our government’s cybersecurity efforts,” said Jordan Wong, a spokesperson for Sen. Claire McCaskill, who was a sponsor of the legislation in the Senate. Offered Ryan Gillis, vice president of cybersecurity strategy and policy at Palo Alto Networks: “The bill rightly gives the Department of Homeland Security the flexibility to organize its cybersecurity and critical infrastructure office to meet today’s threats and challenges, and grants the agency a name that truly matches its mission.”

HAPPY THURSDAY and welcome to Morning Cybersecurity! This is comforting, somehow. Send your thoughts, feedback and especially tips to tstarks@politico.com, and be sure to follow @POLITICOPro and @MorningCybersec. Full team info below.

TODAY: TALKING ICT — The Information and Communications Technology Supply Chain Risk Management Task Force holds its very first meeting today. Announced last month, the task force is a joint government-industry group devoted to identifying and managing supply chain risks in those industries. According to a draft DHS announcement obtained by MC, its government executive committee members include DHS, DoD, DOJ, Commerce, General Services Administration, NTCA-The Rural Broadband Association, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, Social Security Administration and Treasury.

Its industry executive committee members include Accenture, AT&T, CenturyLink, Charter, Cisco, Comcast, CTIA — the Wireless Association, CyberRx, Cybersecurity Coalition, Cyxtera, FireEye, Intel, The Information Technology Industry Council, the IT Information Sharing and Analysis Center, Microsoft, National Association of Broadcasters, NCTA - the Internet and Television Association, Palo Alto Networks, Samsung, Sprint, Threat Sketch, the Telecommunications Industry Association, T-Mobile, USTelecom and Verizon.

TOMORROW: TALKING DIPLOMACY AND CYBERSPACE — Your MC host heads to Brussels for a conference Friday hosted by our POLITICO EU colleagues asking the question, “Is Europe cyber-ready?” I’ll be moderating a chat on the diplomacy piece. Panelists include Antonio Missiroli, NATO’s Assistant Secretary General for Emerging Security Challenges; Carmen Gonsalves, the head of international cyber policy in the Netherlands’ Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Chris Painter, a commissioner on the Global Commission on Stability of Cyberspace and former State Department cyber coordinator; and Patryk Pawlak, Brussels Executive Officer for the EU Institute for Security Studies.

ALL WAIT AND NO PLAY MAKES DoD A DULL BOY — The Pentagon takes too long to acquire new tech, causing DoD to reinvent what’s already commercially available and fall behind on innovation, cybersecurity executives told lawmakers at a Senate Armed Services cyber subcommittee hearing Wednesday. Executives from CrowdStrike, Palo Alto Networks, Core Consulting and Parsons Corporation told lawmakers the private sector faces the same risks as the DoD, but the Pentagon doesn’t take advantage of the threat intelligence already developed by some commercial coalitions like the Cyber Threat Alliance. What’s more, contracts can take years to implement. “If it takes you three years to figure out if the technology is good enough, it’s probably already obsolete by the time you deploy it,” said Dmitri Alperovitch, CrowdStrike chief technology officer.

The DoD also focuses too much on cyber hygiene and passively securing infrastructure and not enough on actively searching for threats, some said. Clearance also poses a significant problem, they said, and potential employees are turning to the private industry simply because it’s faster and easier to get hired.

HEAR YE, HEAR YE — The Defense Intelligence Agency has issued a call to industry outlining potential requirements for its new database. The “broad agency announcement” from the Pentagon’s intelligence armed details four “technical capability” areas that could contribute to the envisioned Machine-Assisted Analytic Rapid-Repository System (MARS), including demonstrating a “flexible, scalable and adaptable data centric environment able to manage and support, at a massive level, a variety of diverse and dynamic data” for multiple kinds of users.

MAGIC 8 BALL SAYS: OUTLOOK NOT SO GOOD — Expect cyberattacks to ramp up at nearly every avenue, FireEye said in a report looking at cybersecurity in 2019 out today. The cybersecurity firm expects nations to take more offensive attacks that deteriorate the traditional rules of engagement. Attacks on cloud infrastructures, mobile devices, e-commerce sites and online banking portals are also expected to increase as tools and attack vectors both grow wider and more easily available.

Russia’s successful disinformation campaign in 2016 has inspired and taught other threat actors, so expect more social media influence operations, FireEye said. Iran and China are expected to ramp up their attacks, as well. One way to slow down the number of attacks is by ensuring hacks carry “risk and repercussions” in the coming year, FireEye said.

RECENTLY ON PRO CYBERSECURITY — The State Department says it’s “not in a position to endorse” a Paris-led accord on cybersecurity. … IRS criminal investigations are increasingly relying on data analytics, according to a report from the agency. … DoD and DHS signed a pact on cybersecurity cooperation.

TWEET OF THE DAY — This is a good conversation regardless of your position on it.

REPORT WATCH

— At least one in three companies experienced a cryptocurrency mining attack in 2017, according to SecureWorks’ latest cybercrime report, released Wednesday. “These infections represent unauthorized access to the network and can affect critical business functions,” the company said. It also found that hackers created more than 257 ransomware variants between July 2017 and June 2018. One of them, GandCrab, spread with remarkable speed and became “the most prevalent ransomware threat in the first half of 2018,” according to the company.

QUICK BYTES

— A New York Times investigation into Facebook sheds light on Russian hacking attempts on the platform and how the social media giant handled disinformation campaigns early on.

— An former U.N. diplomat accused of hacking GOP fundraiser Elliott Broidy has diplomatic immunity, the U.S. says. NBC News

— Researchers found new Meltdown and Spectre attacks. ZDNet

— Researchers found malware in InfoWars’ checkout process. Gizmodo

— Hacker and security researcher Samy Kamkar breaks down hacking in TV and film in a Wired video.

— “He’s supposed to shape Japan’s cybersecurity. He just admitted he doesn’t use computers.” The Washington Post

— Hackers are selling fancy hotel rooms at major discounts. Motherboard

— Trump confidante Roger Stone discussed WikiLeaks plans. NBC News

— Mozilla released a shopping guide on device security.

— “Cybercriminals have returned to old-school manual hacking tactics to boost the efficiency of targeted extortion.” Sophos

— Security researchers won $325,000 in a Tokyo competition for exposing new vulnerabilities in mobile devices. CyberScoop

— The tale of Kevin Mitnick stealing the source code of 1992’s top cell phone while on the road from the government, via Motherboard.

— North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper announced a cybersecurity training initiative for veterans.

— Dragos is opening an office in Saudi Arabia. CyberScoop

That’s all for today.

Stay in touch with the whole team: Mike Farrell (mfarrell@politico.com, @mikebfarrell); Eric Geller (egeller@politico.com, @ericgeller); Martin Matishak (mmatishak@politico.com, @martinmatishak) and Tim Starks (tstarks@politico.com, @timstarks).

Conaway dug in on farm bill

With help from Sarah Zimmerman and Liz Crampton

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Agriculture is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Agriculture subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Agriculture will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22, and Friday, Nov. 23. Our next Morning Ag installment will publish on Monday, Nov. 26.

IN THE HOPPER: In some of the sharpest intra-party sniping yet in farm bill talks, Senate Ag Chairman Pat Roberts on Wednesday blamed his House counterpart Mike Conaway for holding up a potential agreement over concerns spanning at least six titles. Roberts is shooting for a deal as soon as today. Conaway said “we’re going to get a deal done,” but wished talks could remain behind closed doors.

— “Neither one of us is gaining anything by whacking on each other in front of the press,” Conaway said.

— California wine groups and farm bureaus are getting involved in the year-end congressional spending battle, seeking new funds and policy changes to help the state’s wine grape growers deal with damage from catastrophic wildfires. Their sights are set on an emergency funding package in the works for ag producers dealing with this year’s natural disasters.

CONAWAY DEFIANT AS ROBERTS SEEKS DEAL TODAY: House and Senate Agriculture Committee leaders are within striking distance of reaching agreement on a farm bill conference report, as the Senate panel’s top Republican and Democrat see things.

Roberts’ ambitious outlook of a deal being possible today, if realized, would put Congress in good position to pass final legislation before the year ends. But sources tell MA that lawmakers have a ways to go before a deal can be reached.

The loneliest number: As one would expect, the six titles that Roberts says Conaway is dug in on include the commodity, conservation and nutrition sections. But Roberts also said Wednesday that he, Senate Agriculture ranking member Debbie Stabenow and House Ag ranking member Collin Peterson were all on the same page.

“I am very troubled by the fact that we have agreement among three but we can’t get the fourth one,” Roberts said of the Big Four, our Liz Crampton reports. Conaway has been slow to respond to compromise offers, Roberts said, and at one point took 12 days to make a counter-proposal.

“I think we’re close if the House wants to get a farm bill,” Stabenow said, per another dispatch Liz filed from the Hill.

Conaway’s response: The Texas Republican disagreed with the notion that Roberts, Stabenow and Peterson were in accord. “We’ve got some things I haven’t agreed to, they’ve got some things they haven’t agreed to, so you pick your poison as to who you think is standing in the way,” Conaway said.

The House Ag chairman accused Roberts of also not being quick to respond to proposals. Conaway said it took Roberts’ staff eight days to respond to one of Conaway’s offers.

— Bottom line: It’s become increasingly clear that the Big Four are not on the same page about where talks stand, raising more questions about how quickly lawmakers can get a bill done in the lame-duck session.

HAPPY THURSDAY, NOV. 15! Welcome to Morning Ag, where your host could always use a two-hour delay. Have any news or tips? Send ‘em to rmccrimmon@politico.com and @ryanmccrimmon, and follow the whole team @Morning_Ag.

ANOTHER GRIM FORECAST FOR 2019 AG MARKETS: As MA readers well know, 2019 is looking bleak for farmers and ranchers as trade woes mount. A new report out today from Rabobank, a Holland-based banking company focused on agricultural financing, is the latest warning for U.S. agricultural producers to brace for continued trade tension and other threats to commodity prices.

Trade: President Donald Trump’s trade war with China remains the biggest threat, especially for soybean growers. If Beijing’s 25 percent retaliatory tariffs remain in place, the report said U.S. soybean stocks “will easily double.” The bank predicts that Washington’s steep trade deficit with China will make it difficult for the two countries to quickly reach a major deal. But Rabobank saw it as promising that trade negotiators were able to finalize a new North American trade pact in a short span of time.

Pork problems: Rabobank also warns that pork markets could take a hit if the spread of African Swine Fever currently making its way through Chinese livestock herds worsens. Markets would likely shift as they did in response to outbreaks of bird flu, with consumers shifting preferences in consumption.

More bad news: There’s also an 80 percent chance that an El Niño weather pattern could be declared by the end of the winter, which could spell wetter conditions on the Southwestern Plains and the opposite in parts of the Midwest.

“Food producers face a melting pot of risks,” said Justin Sherrard, global strategist for animal protein at Rabobank. “Although it’s possible that not all of them will come to pass, they need to be prepared for a difficult and worrying year in 2019.”

Pros, POLITICO’s Sarah Zimmerman has more on the report here.

CALIFORNIA WINE PRODUCERS SEEK WILDFIRE AID: The state’s wine grape growers want a piece of a potential disaster-assistance package for agricultural producers that Congress might take up in coming weeks or months. Heavy smoke from the deadly blazes has tainted crops, forcing growers to leave grapes withering on the vine or to sell them at a steep discount. Producers also worry that consumer fears of smoke exposure could drive down demand.

Statewide and county winegrower groups and farm bureaus this week wrote to federal lawmakers to make specific policy requests, like extending a federal wildfire indemnity program and promoting access to crop insurance for wine grape growers with smoke exposure claims.

“We urge the inclusion of California winegrape growers in any disaster assistance bill that may move forward,” the groups wrote, citing “substantial economic losses” from the fires, especially in Lake and Mendocino counties.

— Democratic Rep. Mike Thompson, whose district includes Napa Valley and much of Sonoma County, said he’s pushing House appropriators to extend the wildfire indemnity program to include wine grape growers who suffered recent damage.

Tallying up the damage: The wine grape crop in Lake County typically produces $75 million in revenue, the groups said, but now producers there are facing losses of at least $37 million, or roughly 50 percent. (The damage to Malibu vineyards has been extensive as well, The Hollywood Reporter writes.)

— Reps. Robert Aderholt (R-Ala.) and Sanford Bishop (D-Ga.) are working on a spending package to help farmers, ranchers and rural communities recover from natural disasters including Western wildfires and major hurricanes that struck the Southeast. Vineyards appeared to be on the list of potential recipients of the ag aid.

ROW CROPS

— Few changes in leadership ranks: Iowa’s Joni Ernst is the new Senate Republican Conference vice chair, following leadership elections Wednesday, POLITICO’s Burgess Everett reports. Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) was reelected as majority leader and Chuck Schumer will remain the Senate Democratic leader. In the House, Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy was chosen to lead the GOP conference as minority leader next year.

— EU vows swift retaliation if Trump imposes auto tariffs: EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström said Wednesday she has a “draft list” of products “covering lots of different sectors” that would face penalties if Trump slaps duties on the EU auto industry. Pro Trade’s Doug Palmer has more.

— More Malmström: The EU trade chief, who met with U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer in Washington, also warned that prospective U.S.-EU trade talks would likely freeze if the Trump administration keeps pushing for agriculture to be included in a deal — or even if ag is listed as a negotiating objective when the administration sends Congress its trade goals before the talks begin. Doug has that story, too.

— USDA sued over certain labeling procedures: The Animal Welfare Institute sued the Agriculture Department on Wednesday, claiming it failed to mandate third-party audits of food label claims like “humane” and “sustainable.” AWI said USDA hasn’t responded quickly enough to a 2014 petition from the group seeking independent certification of such label claims. More here.

— Trump planning Mississippi visit before Senate runoff: The president is expected to hold a rally for GOP Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith, who’s facing former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy in a runoff on Nov. 27. POLITICO’s Alex Isenstadt has the story.

— U.K. Cabinet signs off on draft Brexit plan: Prime Minister Theresa May’s Cabinet approved the withdrawal agreement between the U.K. and EU after a five-hour meeting, reports POLITICO Brexit Correspondent Charlie Cooper. The agreement now heads to parliament, where it faces an uphill battle for approval. POLITICO Europe’s David M. Herszenhorn has the details of the Brexit plans.

— Consumer Reports wants to know salmonella-linked turkey brands: A week before Thanksgiving, USDA is facing pressure from consumer advocates to name the brands linked to a salmonella outbreak that has sickened more than 160 people in 35 states, including one person who died. Here’s ABC with more.

— More expensive chicken nuggets? Tyson Foods plans to raise prices to compensate for increased expenses related to tariffs, as well as higher labor and freight costs, the company said in its earnings report Tuesday. The Financial Times has more.

THAT’S ALL FOR MA! Same time, same place tomorrow. In the meantime, drop us a line: cboudreau@politico.com and @ceboudreau; rmccrimmon@politico.com and @ryanmccrimmon; hbottemiller@politico.com and @hbottemiller; lcrampton@politico.com and @liz_crampton; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny.

You can also follow @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Ag on Twitter.

Many questions for VA, DoD at hearing

With help from Arthur Allen (@arthurallen202) and Mohana Ravindranath (@ravindranize)

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning eHealth is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro eHealth subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning eHealth will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22 and Friday, Nov. 23. Our next Morning eHealth newsletter will publish on Monday, Nov. 26. Please continue to follow eHealth issues here.

MANY QUESTIONS FOR VA, DoD AT HEARING: Pressure is building on the government’s big EHR project as the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Defense plan to reveal a joint command structure for the software enterprise’s implementation, VA program director John Windom said during a hearing Wednesday.

Members of the House Veterans' Affairs EHR subcommittee quizzed Windom on the lack of clarity about the structure, and some of the allegations in recent media investigations — such as a ProPublica report that the DoD had considered trying to take over the entire EHR project. (Windom denied that one.)

The final versions of the DoD and VA’s EHRs will overlap; matters such as cybersecurity, data hosting structure and patient identity management can be done jointly, Travis Dalton, Cerner's government business lead, testified. Specific differences remain to be ironed out, he said:

"We learned some hard lessons with the DoD implementation, and we're doing a lot of things differently."

— Some Epic questions too: The VA also will brief Congress in December on whether it plans to scrap an Epic scheduling pilot or use both Epic and Cerner systems.

Committee members asked why VA had spent more than $200 million less than budgeted in 2018 as its 10-year estimate for the project jumped from $15.8 billion to $16.1 billion. Windom said the added cost reflected salaries of VA employees that weren’t included in a hurried first estimate.

VA scrubbed an initial plan to staff the EHR modernization office with 700 people, mostly contractors. The plan now is to have to 269 government employees and to draw more heavily on VHA and Office of Information and Technology expertise, Windom said.

eHealth tweet of the day: Thomas Goetz @tgoetz “Just saw a guy take off a smoke mask to have a cigarette.”

THURSDAY: If you had to bet, what present-day phenomenon are you most sure is a fad? (Your correspondent’s answer: most things matcha.) Submit answers at dtahir@politico.com, or socially at @arthurallen202, @dariustahir, @ravindranize, @POLITICOPro and @Morning_eHealth.

TOO MANY MEASURES?: At the Digital Quality Summit, co-held by the National Committee for Quality Assurance and HL7, attendees were forced to grapple with a potentially unwelcome notion: There are too many measures, and paring back means saying “no” to politically powerful entities.

The bearer of the message, David Blumenthal — a former ONC director — said, “We need to decide what not to measure.” Blumenthal based his argument not merely on documentation burden, but also the cognitive demands of responding to measurements. Therefore, he said, the health care system would do better to measure fewer things and more carefully, too. The challenge is compounded by the decentralization of the system; reducing measurement requires getting not merely government but private-sector payors on the same page.

“That is a political challenge — with a small p. Anyone who’s worked in the political system knows patients with problems, and the clinicians who help them do not like to be shunted aside,” he said. But since “no other country is equipping its physicians with scribes,” he added, it’s a challenge worth solving.

Blumenthal also had bullish arguments about Apple and the other tech companies creating tools for consumers to control their health data. “The question that all these tech behemoths are going to be asking themselves is: What will people buy? How can we make this data a consumer item? What will they want to know? What will they open their wallets to get?” he asked. It would mean sidestepping traditional medical power centers — or, as Blumenthal put it, “consumerization of health data … through the backdoor.”

CYBER REPORT: A new report today from medical device manufacturers Abbott and security management advisory firm The Chertoff Group finds that physicians and administrators alike feel underprepared on cybersecurity. According to a survey, about 75 percent of physicians and 62 percent of administrators feel underprepared on their security roles — which include staffing, training and awareness.

The cybersecurity risks are increasing, due not merely to the rise of digital records but also the digital medical devices sprouting everywhere. That means a need for increased standards, particularly in areas around software updates to medical devices (which last a long time). The report will be a subject of discussion during a panel today at US News’s Healthcare of Tomorrow conference — which your correspondent will be moderating, if you needed additional incentive to come.

INSIDE THE HUMPHREY BUILDING

HHS LOOKS AT FUNDING ‘SOCIAL DETERMINANTS’: The Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation is looking into a new care model that could let organizations pay for patients’ social needs, like housing and nutrition, HHS Secretary Alex Azar said Wednesday.

“[W]hat if we went beyond connections and referrals — what if we provided solutions for the whole person, including addressing housing, nutrition and other social needs?” Azar said.

CMMI has an early-stage model, named “Model One,” that could allow for a single payment that an accountable care entity can use to invest in a beneficiary’s broad needs such as transportation, CMMI director Adam Boehler said earlier during the event at the Hatch Center for Civility and Solutions.

The efforts build on the “Accountable Health Communities” model CMMI built last year allowing providers to screen high-needs patients for socioeconomic risks like food insecurity, domestic violence, transportation, housing and utility needs. Those providers then connect beneficiaries with navigators to find relevant social services.

— First in Morning eHealth — Verma to talk telehealth at conference: This morning the CMS administrator is scheduled to address a conference hosted by the Alliance for Connected Care, a telemedicine focused lobbying group. Seema Verma plans to mention CMS’s past and future efforts to cover telehealth under Medicare and the role of technology in value-based care, the agency tells us.

FCC’S PAI TO MEET WITH DAN SULLIVAN: Federal Communications Commission leader Ajit Pai is due to have a meeting with Alaska Sen. Dan Sullivan today over a dispute regarding subsidies from the agency’s rural health care program fund. An Anchorage company wants slightly more in subsidies than the FCC has agreed to give out, and Sullivan is holding up FCC nominees over the dispute. The Pai-Sullivan summit is intended to solve the impasse, our Tech colleagues Margaret Harding McGill and John Hendel report.

WHAT WE'RE CLICKING

Forbes profiles the team behind Flatiron Health

Behind L’Oreal’s clip-on sensor for UV ray exposure

A Nature article discusses the effects of social media on clinical trials (it’s hard to truly blind trials, for example).

A review of two new books on immunotherapy in The Wall Street Journal

APPOINTEE ABYSS: As the 115th Congress approaches its end, key executive-branch positions remain vacant or without permanent leadership at agencies that make employment and immigration policy. With members of Congress set to go home Dec. 14 (barring unforeseen developments), unconfirmed nominees risk having to start the nomination process all over again. Here’s a rundown of those who are in confirmation limbo (with help from the non-profit Partnership for Public Service):

Assistant Secretary for Immigration and Customs Enforcement (a.k.a. ICE director). The nominee, Ronald Vitiello, goes before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee today at 10 a.m. in Dirksen 342. Vitiello, currently deputy director, has been ICE’s acting director since June. Read prepared remarks by Senate HSGAC Chairman Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) here and watch the hearing here.

ICE inspector general. Joseph Cuffari was nominated Nov 1, and his nomination was reported to the Senate Wednesday. The post is currently filled by Deputy IG John V. Kelly (not to be confused with the White House chief of staff, whose middle initial is F).

DOL assistant secretary for employment and training. John Pallasch was nominated in April; no confirmation hearing has been set. Molly Conway has been serving as acting assistant secretary for employment and training.

Assistant Secretary of Labor for Occupational Safety and Health (a.k.a. OSHA chief). Scott Mugno, a former vice president for safety, sustainability & vehicle maintenance at FedEx Ground, was nominated in Oct. 2017, which was thirteen months ago. He was reported favorably out of committee in January, but not yet voted on by the full Senate. Loren Sweatt, deputy assistant secretary for occupational safety and health, has been acting OSHA chief.

DOL assistant secretary for policy. Bryan Jarrett was nominated in July. His nomination was referred to the Senate HELP committee, but no hearings have been held. Jonathan Berry, principal deputy assistant secretary, has been serving as acting assistant secretary for policy.

DOL wage and hour administrator. Cheryl Marie Stanton was nominated in September 2017, which was fourteen months ago. She was reported favorably out of committee in January, but still awaits a floor vote. Bryan Jarrett has been serving as acting administrator.

According to the database tracked by the Partnership for Public Service and The Washington Post, only 50 percent of key DOL positions have been filled so far; at DHS the number is slightly higher, at 65 percent. Take a look at the Post database here.

GOOD MORNING! It’s Nov. 15, and this is Morning Shift, POLITICO's daily tipsheet on employment and immigration policy. Send tips, exclusives, and suggestions to rrainey@politico.com, thesson@politico.com, ikullgren@politico.com and tnoah@politico.com. Follow us on Twitter at @RebeccaARainey, @tedhesson, @IanKullgren and @TimothyNoah1.

BUT WAIT, THERE’S MORE: Some key positions in agencies that make employment and immigration policy have occasioned no nomination at all. Here’s a rundown of those (with help, again, from the non-profit Partnership for Public Service):

DHS deputy secretary. When Elaine Duke vacated this position in April, she was not replaced. The undersecretary for management, Claire Grady, has been acting deputy secretary--and may soon be acting secretary if news reports are correct that President Donald Trump is preparing to fire DHS Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen.

DHS’ chief financial officer. Stacy Marcott, appointed deputy chief financial officer in 2012, has been acting chief financial officer.

Assistant Secretary in the Office of Disability Employment Policy.

DHS undersecretary of the Office of Strategy, Policy, and Plans. This is the person responsible for developing agency policy. The deputy undersecretary, James McCament, has been performing the duties of DHS undersecretary for the office.

UNIONS SUE VA: The National Federation of Federal Employees, the American Federation of Government Employees, and the National Association of Government Employees filed a lawsuit Wednesday challenging the Veterans Affairs Department’s move to “repudiate“ parts of its collective bargaining agreements with employees and reassign more than 400 physicians who work for government unions. (More on that here.) The lawsuit argues that the VA is illegally barring employees from utilizing “official” work time where they can weigh grievances. The VA notice was slated to go into effect today and will impact more than 100,000 employees. Read a press release here and the complaint here.

LAWSUIT CLAIMS ICE TARGETED ACTIVISTS: A federal lawsuit filed Wednesday argues that ICE retaliated against Vermont immigration activists who criticized the agency. The lawsuit, brought by the non-profit Migrant Justice, contends the group’s members were subject to “surveillance, harassment, arrest, and detention.” The complaint cites encounters with ICE dating back to the Obama administration. An ICE spokeswoman said last year that it “does not target individuals based on political beliefs or activism.”

Wages

BERNIE GOES AFTER WALMART: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) today will introduce legislation to pressure Walmart to pay employees $15 an hour, the Washington Post’s Jeff Stein reports. The bluntly named Stop Walmart Act “would bar big corporations from buying their own stock — a move that rewards shareholders — unless they pay all employees $15 an hour, provide them seven days of sick leave, and prevent CEO compensation from rising more than 150 times above median employee pay,” Stein writes.

“Critics say Sanders’s bill would constrict the flow of capital by preventing firms from buying back shares from their investors — money those investors then plow back into to the broader economy. Supporters say the plan would benefit a huge number of underpaid workers as the company’s founders, the Walton family, have seen their wealth balloon dramatically amid a broader increase of wealth inequality in the United States.”

Sanders’ bill is DOA in the Senate, though an identical version by Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.) may get traction in the Democratic-controlled House. More from the Post here. Tune into a conference call briefing on the legislation at 11 a.m. here.

@realDonaldTrump: “Not seen in many years, America’s steelworkers get a hard-earned raise because of my Administration’s policies to help bring back the U.S. steel industry, which is critical to our National Security. I will always protect America and its workers!”

Trump’s tweet yesterday neglected to mention the United Steelworkers union, which threatened a strike if steelmaker didn’t share their windfall from Trump’s tariffs with the rank and file. Union members on Tuesday ratified a new contract with U.S. Steel that includes a 14 percent pay increase over four years.

UNIONS

NURSES UNION-UP: 650 registered nurses in Arcadia, California voted to join the California Nurses Association/National Nurses United on Tuesday, marking the largest non-union hospital gain in Southern California in at least five years, according to the union. Read the press release here.

TEAMSTERS TO DC: Members of the Teamsters union gathered on Capitol Hill Wednesday to put added pressure on Congress to support the Democratic-backed Butch Lewis Act, which would shore up failing pension plans with low-interest federal loans that could be repaid over 30 years. A bipartisan supercommittee faces a Nov. 30 deadline to come up with a bipartisan solution; the expectation is that it won’t.

“It’s time for lawmakers to get back to work and ensure that hard-working Americans who played by the rules all their lives and paid into their retirements get the pensions they were promised,” Teamsters General President Jim Hoffa said. Read the press release here.

title: DeVos’ Title IX rules imminent
description: Gun control movement heartened by midterm gains — Could we see action on FAFSA during the lame-duck session?
content: With help from Caitlin Emma Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Education is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Education subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's compr… [+12020 chars]
fulltext:
DeVos’ Title IX rules imminent

With help from Caitlin Emma

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Education is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Education subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Education will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22, and Friday, Nov. 23. Our next newsletter will publish on Monday, Nov. 26. Please continue to follow Pro Education issues here.

DEVOS’ TITLE IX RULES IMMINENT: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is set to unveil as soon as this week her proposed rules for schools handling allegations of sexual harassment and assault. DeVos has said her controversial rewrite of the rules — which she announced after scrapping Obama-era guidance last year — is aimed at bolstering the rights of accused students.

— The department is planning to unveil the proposal on Friday, multiple sources told Morning Education — though the exact timing could change. The proposal was still being reviewed by OMB late Wednesday.

— Democrats are ready to pounce. The rewrite is among the most controversial moves she’s made since taking office and Democrats are sure to target it as they wield their newfound control of the House to call DeVos and her aides to testify on Capitol Hill.

— A preview of what’s to come: The Title IX rules will be a main topic of discussion in a roundtable that Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif) is hosting this afternoon with members of Congress, civil rights advocates and student leaders. It’s at 3:30 p.m. in Cannon House Office Building Room 421.

— DeVos’ proposal is expected to mostly stick with changes included in leaked drafts, which sparked intense pushback from women’s advocacy groups earlier this summer. Those groups argue the new rules will put up roadblocks for victims seeking justice. The leaked draft drew praise from civil liberties and men’s rights groups who say Obama-era rules pushed schools to trample due process.

— “We are very committed to a rule that will respect all parties,” DeVos told National Review this month. “It’s also important that institutions have a framework they can rely on, and that all parties can rely on.”

— The rules are expected to: More narrowly define sexual harassment, let schools use a higher standard of evidence for discipline decisions and allow them to offer mediation to resolve cases. They are also expected to hold schools responsible only for allegations involving misconduct that occurred on campus, among other changes.

— One major change: The rules are expected to guarantee students have a chance to cross-examine their accusers. The students could be in separate rooms and the questions could be delivered by third parties. It’s a major departure from Obama-era guidelines that discouraged the practice, which survivors’ advocates say is traumatizing.

— “This rule will return schools back to a time where rape, assault and harassment were swept under the rug,” said Jess Davidson, executive director of End Rape on Campus. “This rule enables schools to be a safe place to get away with committing sexual violence, rather than a safer place to learn free from violence.”

— Civil liberties groups have praised DeVos’ efforts. Based on the leaked draft, at least, the new rules “are a dramatic improvement over the previous guidance,” said Samantha Harris, vice president for procedural advocacy at the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education. She praised the department for launching a formal rulemaking process and said she believes the rules balance the rights of both victims and accused: “It’s important that allegations aren’t ignored and aren’t prejudged.”

IT’S THURSDAY. WE’RE ALMOST THERE. THIS IS MORNING EDUCATION. It's officially cold out, which, for me, means it's time for "Cold Roses." Tips? Feedback? Let me know: bwermund@politico.com or @BenjaminEW. Share event listings: educalendar@politicopro.com. And follow us on Twitter: @Morning_Edu and @POLITICOPro.

School Safety

GUN CONTROL MOVEMENT HEARTENED BY MIDTERM GAINS: More than two dozen Democrats endorsed by gun control advocates were newly elected to the House in the last week. The nonprofit Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence devoted the most energy to unseating the “Notorious Nine” — incumbent Republican House members who’ve received A or A-plus ratings from the National Rifle Association. Of those nine, seven lost their races, only one came out victorious and another race still hasn’t been called.

— The gun control movement of 2018 ignited by the Parkland school shooting is taking credit for helping secure these new House seats for Democrats. And with the lower chamber flipping blue, advocates are bullish about passage of a background checks bill, even if it likely will fail in the Senate. While guns weren’t a top issue for most voters, according to exit polls, advocates and experts say they believe the Florida school shooting that killed 17 people led to more gun control supporters in Congress and helped drive more young people to the polls.

— All eyes on Florida: Advocates and some Parkland survivors and parents who were initially disappointed by Florida on Election Day also have new hope. The governor’s race and the Senate race are embroiled in a recount, leaving open the possibility that Florida might still elect a progressive governor and senator who embrace gun control in a state where the NRA has historically had a strong hold. Caitlin Emma has the story.

HIGHER EDUCATION

A LITTLE LAME-DUCK ACTION: The top Republican and Democrat on the Senate HELP Committee are pushing a bipartisan bill to allow the IRS and Education Department to share more student data. It’s a step toward simplifying the application for federal student aid that has long been a goal of Chairman Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.) — and one that he and Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.) hope to get through Congress in the coming weeks, a difficult feat in a lame-duck session.

— The “co-sponsors hope to pass this legislation before the new Congress,” a HELP committee spokesman told Morning Education. The FAFSA Act, S. 3611 (115), is also co-sponsored by Sheldon Whitehouse (D-R.I.) and Cory Gardner (R-Colo.).

— The bill would amend the the Internal Revenue Code, which currently prohibits the IRS from sharing taxpayer data with the Education Department. It would allow the IRS to disclose tax return information to department officials “determining eligibility for, and amount of, Federal student financial aid." More on that here.

ANTI-AFFIRMATIVE ACTION CANDIDATES STRUGGLE IN MIDTERMS: Rep. Mimi Walters (R-Calif.) has slowly lost the lead this week in her reelection bid in which she vowed to push for the House to investigate “discrimination against Asian-American students at Ivy League and other top universities.” The pitch was on a mailer praising a Justice Department investigation into such allegations at Yale.

— Walters was one of at least two candidates that attacked affirmative action in a bid to win over Asian-American voters. The other was Corey Stewart, who lost a bid to unseat Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Va.) by 16 points. In California, Walters is still engaged in a tight race that she led by more than 6,000 votes on election night. Walters now trails her Democratic challenger, Katie Porter, by just a couple hundred votes.

SPEAKING OF: The federal judge weighing allegations that Harvard is discriminating against Asian-American applicants approved a schedule for how the arguments will play out going forward. Both Harvard and the group suing it, Students for Fair Admissions, will each submit 75 pages or less making their final arguments in December and they’ll each get a chance to submit written responses in January. Another round of oral arguments are expected in Boston in February.

HBCUS WARM TO DEVOS: Presidents of historically black colleges and universities presented DeVos with a plaque Wednesday, thanking her for her work on a capital financing program that's helped their financially struggling schools — a shift from the cold shoulder DeVos received at one HBCU in 2017.

— "We thanked her and gave her a plaque which we hope she will place prominently in her office, which is an expression of our appreciation," said Michael Lomax, the president of the United Negro College Fund — commonly known as UNCF. UNCF works on behalf of 36 private HBCUs. The meeting in DeVos' office lasted about an hour. It included several presidents whose schools have benefited from the Education Department's work with the HBCU Capital Financing Program.

— Several of the presidents extended an invitation to DeVos to visit if she's in their communities, Lomax said, adding: "Those were heartfelt, I think, invitations." Kimberly Hefling has the full story.

ANALYSIS: SCHOOL IMPROVEMENT PLANS NEED IMPROVEMENT: Just 17 states have made enough information publicly available to detail their plans for improving low-performing schools under the Every Student Succeeds Act, a new analysis concludes. The nonprofit Collaborative for Student Success teamed up with HCM Strategists, a public policy and consulting firm, to review how states are approaching school improvement under the law.

— Less than half of the 17 states reviewed require districts to demonstrate how their proposed strategies for improving low-performing schools “will address historic inequities — such as access to high quality teachers, a rigorous curriculum, enrichment opportunities and closing the achievement gap,” the review says. Read more.

MOVERS AND SHAKERS

— Marian Wright Edelman is stepping down as president of the Children’s Defense Fund and will assume a new role of president emerita. CDF will begin a search for a new president and Max Lesko will become national executive director on Dec. 31, overseeing day-to-day operations and reporting to the board of directors. Lesko, CDF’s chief of staff, worked in the Obama administration as chief of staff for the Education Department’s Office for Civil Rights, among other things. More.

— The Council of Chief State School Officers, which represents state education leaders nationwide, announced its new board of directors. Pedro Rivera, secretary of education in Pennsylvania, assumed the presidency and Jillian Balow, superintendent of public instruction in Wyoming, was chosen as president-elect.

REPORT ROLL CALL

— The National Council on Disability is out with two reports today on the impact of school choice policies on students with disabilities, which the reports find vary considerably across the country. Read them here.

— Have we been too focused on STEM education? A new report from the American Enterprise Institute suggests as much: “Labor market data and employer feedback suggests the emphasis on STEM in workforce development is obscuring deeper, widespread challenges to employability relating to noncognitive skills associated with persistence and character, particularly for middle-skill occupations.”

— In a new report, the GAO says the VA needs to come up with a plan to make sure schools receiving VA education benefits are complying with program requirements and that veterans receive the education they have been promised.

SYLLABUS

— College Board vows the testing organization will work with its member colleges to find ways to recruit students that go beyond SAT scores: POLITICO Pro.

— Detroit school board member says naming school after Ben Carson “is synonymous with having Trump’s name on our school in blackface”: The Washington Post.

— Pennsylvania teachers union files suit to overturn a policy allowing teachers and other employees to carry guns in school: AP.

— Former Florida charter school owner gets 20 years in prison in fraud case: Pensacola News Journal.

— University of Wisconsin-La Crosse chancellor apologizes for booking longtime adult film actress and sex educator during ‘Free Speech Week’: ‘Regrettably, in many media headlines and accounts, the speaker’s profession completely overwhelmed her message.’: La Crosse Tribune.

Let it ride, let it roll, let it go. Follow the Pro Education team. @caitlinzemma (cemma@politico.com), @khefling (khefling@politico.com), @mstratford (mstratford@politico.com), @BenjaminEW (bwermund@politico.com), @MelLeonor_ (mleonor@politico.com) and @JaneNorman (jnorman@politico.com).

title: Ocasio-Cortez’s ‘Green New Deal’ becomes flash point for Pelosi
description: The tension within the party comes as Pelosi is racing to secure the support she will need to claim the House speaker's gavel.
content: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is gathering support for a resolution that would establish a select House committee to develop legislation on the Green New Deal | Win McNamee/Getty Images Nancy Pelosi is facing an unexpected flare-up on climate change that is compli… [+6932 chars]
fulltext:
Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is gathering support for a resolution that would establish a select House committee to develop legislation on the Green New Deal. | Win McNamee/Getty Images Energy & Environment Ocasio-Cortez’s ‘Green New Deal’ becomes flash point for Pelosi

Nancy Pelosi is facing an unexpected flare-up on climate change that is complicating relationships among House Democrats ahead of crucial leadership elections.

Incoming liberals, led by Rep.-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, are demanding Pelosi go beyond her promise to revive a select committee on global warming; they want her and the rest of the Democratic Caucus to back an ambitious plan to transition the economy to 100 percent renewable energy in a little more than a decade.

Story Continued Below

But the party's chairmen-in-waiting are pushing back on the idea that even a new select committee would be necessary, arguing that the existing Energy and Commerce, Natural Resources, Transportation and Science committees have the tools they need to address climate change.

The tension within the party comes as Pelosi is racing to secure the support she will need to claim the House speaker's gavel when Democrats take the majority next year, and amid broader tension between moderate members worried about overreaching and progressives who see bold proposals as the key to the party's future. The new climate plan goes well beyond the Obama-era cap-and-trade climate policy that House Democrats embraced before losing their previous majority in 2010 — but since then, renewable energy's costs have plummeted while its popularity has risen in key electoral states like Colorado.

While she is confident she will prevail, Pelosi faces a thin margin for error and has launched an intense campaign to round up the support she will need, and Democrats are using that vulnerability to attempt to secure concessions on a host of issues.

Morning Energy newsletter The source for energy and environment news — weekday mornings, in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Climate activists are urging Ocasio-Cortez and other liberals to consider withholding their support for Pelosi's bid to be speaker without additional concessions.

Pelosi's record "doesn't give us confidence that she is ready to do what it takes in the next two years. ... She wants to reintroduce this select committee on climate change, but basically all she wants it to do, from what we can tell, is convene people to talk about the science," said Evan Weber, national political director with the Sunrise Movement, an organizer of protests outside Pelosi's office on Tuesday. "We’ve been talking about the science for the past few decades.”

Ocasio-Cortez is gathering support for a resolution that would establish a select House committee to develop legislation on the Green New Deal, a set of ambitious principles that progressives envision as a work-in-progress Democratic Party platform on climate change.

“I don’t want to see Miami underwater, I don’t want to see my own district underwater, and I know that Leader Pelosi doesn’t, either,” Ocasio-Cortez told reporters Tuesday as she joined protesters at the leader's office. “What we need to show her is that we’re here to back her up in pushing for 100 percent renewable energy and we’re here to support that kind of bold, progressive leadership.”

Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.) and incoming members Deb Haaland (D-N.M.), Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.) and Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) have all endorsed the Green New Deal resolution. Other liberals, like Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.), have not endorsed the Ocasio-Cortez resolution but backed similarly ambitious legislation like transitioning the U.S. to 100 percent clean energy by 2050. Most have remained coy on whether they'll support Pelosi on the floor.

The Green New Deal resolution calls for a bevy of far-reaching liberal goals to decarbonize the economy within a decade by reshaping the electric power, agriculture and transportation sector, but it includes few details outlining how to get there. That is likely too ambitious even for many Democrats — and would stand zero chance of getting past Senate Republicans or President Donald Trump — but the concept has become an important rallying cry for the need to address climate change.

“Whether or not it’s called the Green New Deal, I think there will be significant pieces of [an infrastructure package] that will touch on climate,” Jayapal told POLITICO. “There are lots of ideas out there that aren’t called Green New Deal but are addressing similar kinds of issues.”

Pelosi created the Select Committee on Energy Independence and Global Warming when she was first elected speaker in 2007, but Republicans eliminated the committee when they took the majority in 2011. Now, a growing number of senior Democrats say they don't know whether the panel needs to come back.

"As co-chairs of the Safe Climate Caucus, we believe that the committees of jurisdiction and future Chairs are ready and able to tackle this challenge," Reps. Don Beyer (D-Va.) and Alan Lowenthal (D-Calif.) wrote in a letter to Pelosi on Wednesday. "However, should you decide to create a select committee on climate change in the 116th Congress, we stand ready to work with you."

The letter from Beyer and Lowenthal came a few hours after three Democratic chairmen-in-waiting — Energy and Commerce ranking member Frank Pallone (D-N.J.), Science ranking member Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-Texas) and Natural Resources ranking member Raúl Grijalva (D-Ariz.) — announced they would be holding climate change hearings early next year, in an apparent attempt to protect their turf. "Our committees plan to work closely together to aggressively assess the public health, economic and environmental impacts of climate change and to explore the best solutions to combat this challenge," they said in a statement.

Grijalva, a member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus who has said he plans to back Pelosi, said he understood why Ocasio-Cortez and others are pushing leadership to be more aggressive in attacking climate change. “I would agree with some of their criticism. We’re baby-stepping it,” he told reporters Wednesday.

But climate change wasn’t a top issue most Democrats campaigned on in a wave election, and the incoming majority is expected instead to focus on health care, infrastructure and conducting oversight on the Trump administration.

Republicans will likely paint any Democratic plan to address climate change as too expensive, but activists say Democrats should not fear such attacks from a party that has overseen growing deficits and did not pay for its massive tax cut last year.

“I’m not interested in entertaining that question given the full board of what Republicans have funded most recently with the tax cut,” said Vijay Das, a senior campaign strategist with the public policy organization Demos who has been working on the Green New Deal concept. “To be perfectly blunt, fiscal conservatives don’t have to answer this question when they’re making decisions to embolden the 1 percent.”

That’s not to say Republicans won’t make the argument anyway.

“Green New Deal? Sounds like a lot of red ink,” Sen. Cory Gardner (R-Colo.) told POLITICO.

Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto won a tough race in 2016 against former GOP Rep. Joe Heck to take the seat previously held by Democratic Leader Harry Reid. | AP Photo/Scott Sonner Congress Cortez Masto named DSCC chair

Nevada Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto was named chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee on Thursday.

The freshman Democrat will steer the committee into a cycle when Democrats have a real shot at taking back the majority. Republicans will have no more than 53 seats pending the recount in the Florida Senate race, and a handful of GOP senators are considered vulnerable in the 2020 presidential election year.

Story Continued Below

News of her being tapped to lead the DSCC was first reported by POLITICO.

Democrats announced the rest of their leadership team on Wednesday, but Cortez Masto was still negotiating with Democratic leaders about the position. She was interested in a spot on the Senate Finance Committee, according to one Senate Democratic source.

Cortez Masto won a tough race in 2016 against former GOP Rep. Joe Heck to take the seat previously held by Democratic Leader Harry Reid.

ZINKE: 'Now is not the time to point fingers' -- GAVIN: The new 'alpha dog' in Sacramento? -- PPIC POLL: Majority backs 'split roll' reform of Prop. 13 -- AVENATTI arrested for felony domestic violence -- 'STEYER EFFECT' on youth vote?

THE BUZZ: Federal and California officials put aside their quarrel over the cause of state's deadliest-ever wildfire Wednesday as Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke joined Gov. Jerry Brown to tour the area north of Sacramento devastated by the disaster.

-- Speaking to reporters after viewing the incinerated ruins of an elementary school in the fire-ravaged town of Paradise, Zinke and Brown emphasized cooperation and refrained from casting blame for the fires — a marked departure from Donald Trump’s recent statements faulting California.

Story Continued Below

-- “He’s pledged the full resources of the federal government,” Brown said of Trump, adding that “now is the time for solidarity and understanding, and let’s learn how to do this together in the best way we can.”

-- ZINKE DEFLECTED QUESTIONS about Trump’s critiques as well as his own charges of mismanagement in California. “There’s a lot of reasons for fires. Now is not the time to point fingers,” Zinke said, calling metastasizing wildfires not an exclusively state or federal matter but, "an American issue of managing our forests," and noting that the soaring federal price tag for massive fires had reached $870 million. Read the full story by POLITICO’s Jeremy B. White.

BUENOS DÍAS, Good THURSDAY morning. Possible 2020 candidate Michael Avenatti was arrested Wednesday on a domestic violence charge, which he’s strongly denying. Gavin Newsom got some good news (a surplus), and some challenging news (he’ll have to fight fellow Democrats over it). And Kevin McCarthy gets the votes for minority leader as Nancy Pelosi fights tooth and nail for the Speaker's gavel.

QUOTE OF THE DAY: "I think the fact that we have won the House majority because of women candidates with huge women turnout, to then deny the first woman speaker who led us to that victory the gavel I think would be a slap in the face of a lot of voters who sent us here." Rep. Ro Khanna to Washington Post Congressional reporter Erica Warner

BONUS QUOTE OF THE DAY: Newly-designated House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, channeling Arnold Schwarzenegger as “Terminator”: “We’ll be back.” via the Washington Examiner.

-- TWEET OF THE DAY: @realDonaldTrump (moments before Brown-Zinke meeting): “Just spoke to Governor Jerry Brown to let him know that we are with him, and the people of California, all the way!”

-- WHERE'S JERRY? Brown will hold a media availability at the conclusion of a private briefing at the Incident Command Post in Camarillo, and will later attend the memorial service for Ventura County Sheriff’s Sgt. Ron Helus in Westlake Village.

-- WHERE'S GAVIN? Nothing official announced.

CALIFORNIA ON FIRE

-- “The Interior Secretary Says The California Wildfires Are “Worse Than Any War Zone I Saw In Iraq” via Blake Montgomery in Buzzfeed: “It’s one of the worst disasters I’ve seen in my career, hands down,” FEMA Administrator Brock Long also said after surveying damage. Story.

HILLS FIRE (Ventura County) -- 4,500 acres, 90 percent contained.

THE MIDTERMS

-- THE WAY IT’S GOING -- The shrinking GOP Caucus is down to 8 in California and looks increasingly like we could end up with a 100 percent Democratic delegation in Orange County — the home of the Reagan Revolution..

THE HOT RACES:

-- CA-10: GOP Rep. Jeff Denham concedes, while the third-place finisher in this year's primary, Republican Ted Howze, says he's considering running against Democratic Rep.-elect Josh Harder, via Modesto Bee.

Expressed by percentage points, this one is locked at 50 percent to 50 percent. But MSNBC’s Steve Kornacki says by Thursday night, based on the trend here, this could well be a Dem pickup.

-- CA-45: After pulling ahead of GOP Rep. Mimi Walters by 261 votes last night, Democrat Katie Porter bolstered her lead to a more robust 3,797 votes.

FIRST IN PLAYBOOK -- THE STEYER EFFECT ON YOUTH VOTE? Tom Steyer’s NextGen America had a goal of registering 250,000 voters, aged 18-35, which it exceeded by at least 10,000 in the midterms, the organization said this week.

--- AND IN CALIFORNIA, particularly, it appears that some of the NextGen efforts to boost Millennial voting and student voting near key universities and colleges may have delivered a key difference in critical House races. Among those who appeared to benefit: CA-45 Democratic candidate Katie Porter, a UC Irvine professor, who has now pulled ahead of Rep. Mimi Walters, in part due to the campus youth vote that was this year more than 10 times the 2014 turnout.

title: Trump revives personal attacks against Mueller team
description: Trump claimed that the special counsel’s office has “found no collusion and have gone absolutely nuts.”
content: President Donald Trump on Thursday called Special Counsel Robert Muellers team a disgrace to our Nation and said that the investigators dont care how many lives [they] ruin. | AP Photo/Andrew Harnik President Donald Trump erupted at special counsel Robert Mue… [+2064 chars]
fulltext:
President Donald Trump on Thursday called Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s team “a disgrace to our Nation” and said that the investigators “don’t care how many lives [they] ruin.” | AP Photo/Andrew Harnik White House Trump revives personal attacks against Mueller team

President Donald Trump erupted at special counsel Robert Mueller on Twitter on Thursday morning, calling the special counsel's Russia probe a “witch hunt like no other in American history,” lashing out at Mueller’s team and firing off baseless accusations of corruption as the White House reportedly negotiates whether and when the president will provide a written response to questions from investigators.

Trump called the investigation, which is focused on whether Trump or his 2016 campaign team conspired with the Russian government to interfere in the 2016 election, “a total mess,” and claimed that the special counsel’s office has “found no collusion and have gone absolutely nuts.”

Story Continued Below

Trump’s broadsides against the Mueller investigation are some of the most direct in recent weeks, reviving past attacks against Mueller’s time as FBI director in the Obama administration and calling for the investigation of “bad acts and crimes on the other side.”

Mueller’s team is “screaming and shouting at people, horribly threatening them to come up with the answers they want,” Trump claimed, without elaborating.

One of the president’s attorneys, Rudy Giuliani, said last week that Trump’s legal team had prepared written responses for him to review, and said that Trump needed to decide whether or not to send the responses to Mueller’s team. That decision was likely to come sometime this week, once Trump returned from his weekend trip to Paris, he said.

Playbook PM Sign up for our must-read newsletter on what's driving the afternoon in Washington. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Giuliani confirmed that Mueller’s questions dealt solely with the time before Trump was sworn into office, rather than whether or not Trump sought to obstruct justice and upend the investigation.

Whether Trump would respond to questions from the special counsel has been a point of negotiation for over a year, as Trump has insisted he wants to sit for an interview, a move his legal team has advised against out of fear that the president might perjure himself. The disagreement over how to approach an interview with Mueller reportedly prompted one of his top lawyers, John Dowd, to resign earlier this year.

Trump on Thursday called Mueller’s team “a disgrace to our Nation” and said that the investigators “don’t care how many lives [they] ruin.”

In another set of tweets, Trump returned to an old and debunked line of attack to suggest that Mueller’s lack of Senate confirmation as special counsel made him ineligible to oversee the probe. He also lobbed an accusation, without evidence, that Mueller, whose mandate is to investigate Russian interference, is protecting “all of his friends on the other side,” listing off former FBI officials he views as corrupt, as well as his 2016 opponent Hillary Clinton.

“Universities will someday study what highly conflicted (and NOT Senate approved) Bob Mueller and his gang of Democrat thugs have done to destroy people,” Trump wrote.

Trump’s Twitter flurry continued with a post calling instead for an investigation of Democrats for “collusion” and of “biased” sites like Facebook, Twitter and Google.

author: asarkissian@politico.com (Arek Sarkissian)
title: Florida judge extends deadline for fixing ballots with mismatched signatures
description: Judge Walker stresses in the ruling county elections supervisors should just count the rejected ballots.
content: Walkers ruling is the result of a challenge filed last week by Democratic Sen. Bill Nelson s reelection campaign against GOP Gov. Rick Scott. | Wilfredo Lee/AP Photo A Tallahassee federal court judge has given voters until Saturday to fix ballots that were to… [+2414 chars]
fulltext:
Walker’s ruling is the result of a challenge filed last week by Democratic Sen. Bill Nelson’s reelection campaign against GOP Gov. Rick Scott. | Wilfredo Lee/AP Photo Florida judge extends deadline for fixing ballots with mismatched signatures

TALLAHASSEE — A Tallahassee federal court judge has given voters until Saturday to fix ballots that were tossed due to conflicting signatures, extending the deadline for counties to turn in final election results, including machine recounts.

Judge Mark Walker determined Thursday that state law lacks a concrete process for voters to challenge county canvassing boards that decided to reject provisional or vote-by-mail ballots due to signature mismatches.

Story Continued Below

The ruling is likely to extend the machine recount portion of one of two U.S. Senate contests that remain to be called. The margin in the Florida race is so slim that it is almost certain to proceed to a manual recount after the machine recount concludes.

But though it could affect thousands of ballots, the ruling would likely not be enough on its own to reverse the 12,562 vote deficit Sen. Bill Nelson faces in his reelection against Gov. Rick Scott.

Walker noted in the ruling he handed down Thursday morning that the law also “interestingly” allows voters to challenge an acceptable signature match, but not defend one that was rejected.

“The precise issue in this case is whether Florida’s law that allows county election officials to reject vote-by-mail and provisional ballots for mismatched signatures — with no standards, an illusory process to cure, and no process to challenge the rejection — passes constitutional muster,” Walker wrote. “The answer is simple. It does not.”

Walker’s ruling is the result of a challenge filed last week by Nelson’s reelection campaign against Scott. Nelson’s lawyer asked during a Wednesday hearing for at least a month to alert at least 3,700 voters whose ballots had been rejected. Walker, instead, hinted at a Sunday deadline. Voters now have until Saturday at 5 p.m.

However, the ruling might not apply to all of those ballots. Walker narrowly tailored the decision to those “voters who have been belatedly notified [by election supervisors that] they have submitted a mismatched-signature ballot.” That number is unclear.

Walker stresses in the ruling county elections supervisors should not just count the rejected ballots. The extended deadline is merely an opportunity for voters to come forward with information that would confirm their signature.

"Let this Court be clear: it is NOT ordering county canvassing boards to count every mismatched vote, sight unseen,” Walker wrote. "Rather, the county supervisors of elections are directed to allow those voters who should have had an opportunity to cure their ballots in the first place to cure their vote-by-mail and provisional ballots now, before the second official results are fully counted.”

Walker also rejected a motion Scott’s lawyers made to delay the impact of his decision pending the result of the appellate review. Scott’s lawyers filed an appeal this morning shortly after Walker published his decision. Scott has consistently led as the votes have been tallied.

Marc Caputo contributed to this report.

title: Despite staffing turmoil, Trump promises White House 'running very smoothly'
description: The media, Trump said, had overhyped personnel moves.
content: More changes could still be coming for the Trump administration, with President Donald Trump himself hinting for weeks that he would make personnel moves following the midterms. | AP Photo/Andrew Harnik President Donald Trump insisted Thursday that despite a … [+2180 chars]
fulltext:
More changes could still be coming for the Trump administration, with President Donald Trump himself hinting for weeks that he would make personnel moves following the midterms. | AP Photo/Andrew Harnik White House Despite staffing turmoil, Trump promises White House 'running very smoothly'

President Donald Trump insisted Thursday that despite a recent flurry of high-level reshuffling inside his administration, with more reportedly on the way, his White House "is running very smoothly."

The media, Trump said, had overhyped personnel moves, which have included the removal of Jeff Sessions as attorney general and the reassignment of deputy national security adviser Mira Ricardel.

Story Continued Below

“The White House is running very smoothly and the results for our Nation are obviously very good. We are the envy of the world,” he wrote in a tweet. “But anytime I even think about making changes, the FAKE NEWS MEDIA goes crazy, always seeking to make us look as bad as possible! Very dishonest!”

Administration turnover is common in the wake of midterm elections, but the churn in the Trump White House is at record levels less than two years into his first term. Less than 24 hours after Election Day, Trump fired Sessions, replacing him on an acting basis with Sessions’ chief of staff, Matthew Whitaker, a move that critics have called legally and ethically questionable.

And on Tuesday, first lady Melania Trump took the unusual step of publicly announcing her opposition to Ricardel. Ricardel was removed from her post Wednesday and is expected to be reassigned elsewhere in the administration.

COUNTDOWN TO 2020 The race for 2020 starts now. Stay in the know. Follow our presidential election coverage. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

More changes could still be coming for the Trump administration, with the president himself hinting for weeks that he would make personnel moves following the midterms. White House chief of staff John Kelly, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen and Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke have all been reported as possibly on the move in coming days and weeks.

Trump also has yet to name a permanent replacement for Scott Pruitt, his former Environmental Protection Agency administrator, who was fired this summer after a series of probes into ethics breaches, or Nikki Haley, his ambassador to the United Nations, who will step down at the end of the year.

title: Pence says second Trump-Kim summit will focus on creating 'verifiable' denuclearization plan
description: And without a plan, "we're going to keep the pressure on," vice president says.
content: President Donald Trump chats with North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un during their first summit in Singapore on June 12, 2018. | Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images The second summit between President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un will focus on creati… [+2525 chars]
fulltext:
President Donald Trump chats with North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un during their first summit in Singapore on June 12, 2018. | Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images defense Pence says second Trump-Kim summit will focus on creating 'verifiable' denuclearization plan

The second summit between President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un will focus on creating a “verifiable plan” for North Korea’s denuclearization, Vice President Mike Pence said Thursday, but an accounting of Pyongyang's nuclear weapons and testing sites will not be a prerequisite for the meeting.

In an interview with NBC News, Pence argued that the Trump administration has made “tremendous progress” in denuclearization talks, despite a new report that showed North Korea may still be developing more than a dozen missile testing sites and the recent cancellation of a meeting between the countries' top diplomats.

Story Continued Below

The U.S. has pushed North Korea for an inventory of its weapons stockpile as well as a list of its ballistic missile testing sites, requests Pyongyang has resisted, asking first for sanctions relief, something Pence said would not happen until total denuclearization is achieved.

“Until we have a plan — and that plan is implemented — to achieve complete, verifiable, irreversible denuclearization, we're going to keep the pressure on,” he said, noting that in his view, past administrations erred by securing promises from North Korea that it would shut down its nuclear weapons program and sanctions relief was given, only for North Korea to continue developing weapons.

Negotiations between the two countries, while apparently ongoing, have hit a rough patch over the timing of sanctions relief, with North Korea asking for concessions from the U.S. in return for its initial steps to dismantle its nuclear programs.

Developing a concrete plan to identify North Korea’s nuclear weapons and ballistic missile sites and verify when they are shut down will be “absolutely imperative” in the second meeting, set for sometime next year, Pence said Thursday.

Morning Defense newsletter Sign up for Morning Defense, a daily briefing on Washington's national security apparatus. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

The first meeting between Trump and Kim — the first ever between top leaders of the U.S. and the isolated communist country — focused on achieving an initial agreement to wind down nuclear weapons programs, and was part of broader efforts to form a relationship with North Korean leaders, Pence said.

“Everything begins with relationships,” he said, “but now we need to see results.”

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was set to meet with his North Korean counterpart earlier this month, ahead of a second meeting between Pompeo and Kim, but that meeting was postponed at the last minute.
